4. Atrb: see 1, in three places.

Atrbhu He put dust, or earth, upon it, (S, M, A, K,) namely, a thing; (S, M;) as also trRbhu↓: (A, K:) or the latter, inf. n. tatoriybN, signifies he defiled it, or soiled it, (namely, a thing,) with dust, or earth: (S:) or you say, tarabahu↓, (TA,) or tarabahu biAltRuraAbi, (Msb,) aor.
tariba
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. tarobN, (TA,) [meaning he sprinkled it with dust,] namely, a writing [for the purpose of drying up the ink], (Msb,) or a paper; (TA;) and trRbhu↓, (T, Msb, TA,) with teshdeed, (Msb,) [meaning he sprinkled much dust upon it; or sprinkled it much with dust;] namely, a writing; (T, Msb, TA;) the latter having an intensive signification: (Msb:) or ↓the former of the last two verbs is used in speaking of anything that is improved, or put into a right or proper state [by means of dust or earth]; and ↓the latter of them, in speaking of anything that is injured or marred or spoiled [thereby]: you say, AlUihaAba tarabati↓ [She sprinkled, or put, dust, or earth, upon the hide], to prepare it properly for use; and so of a skin for water or milk. (TA.) It is said in a trad., [accord. to one reading,] AtoribuwA AlkitaAba [Sprinkle ye the writing with dust]. (S. [So in three copies of that work: probably OatoribuwA; but perhaps AitoribuwA↓: the reading commonly known is tarRibuwA↓.])
Atrb also signifies He possessed a slave who had been possessed three times. (T, K.)
5. ttrRb He, (T,) or it, (S,) became defiled, or soiled, (T, S,) in the dust, or earth, (T,) or with dust, or earth: (S:) it had dust, or earth, sticking to it. (M.)
tarobN: see turaAbN.
turobN: see turaAbN, in three places.

tirobN One born at the same time with thee; (M, K;) a coëtanean; a contemporary in birth; an equal in age: an equal; a match; a fellow; a peer, or compeer: syn. lidapN: (T, S, M, A, K:) and sinRN: (M, A, K:) applied to a male and to a female; (TA;) but mostly to a female; (M;) or, accord. to an opinion confirmed by [most of] the leading lexicologists, only to a female; and sinRN is applied, as also qaronN, to a male; and lidapN, to a male and a female: (TA:) pl. OatoraAbN. (S, M, A.) [The following exs. are given.] You say, [applying it to a female,] hecihi tirobu hecihi, (T, S,) and hiIa tirobuhaA, (M,) and hiIa tirobiI; (K;) and [applying it to females and males,] humaA tirobaAni, (T, A,) and hunRa OatoraAbN, (S, A,) and humo OatoraAbN. (A.) Accord. to Th, EurubFA OatorabFA, in the Kur [lvi. 36], means [Showing love to their husbands;] like, or equal, unto them, or resembling them: which is a good rendering, as there is no begetting or bearing of children, [or rather as the latter word does not apply to females born or generated,] in that case. (TA.)

taribN, applied to a place, (M, TA,) and to soil, (TA,) Abounding with dust; dusty: (T, M, TA:) and to food, (T,) or flesh-meat, (A,) defiled, or soiled, (T, A,) in the dust, (T,) or with dust. (A.) You say also OaroDN tarobaMCu↓ meaning Land in which are dust and moist earth. (M.) And riyHN taribapN, (T, S, M,) and taribN, (T,) A wind that carries with it dust: (T:) or that brings dust: (S:) or that drives along the dust: [or having dust: for] thus used it is a possessive epithet. (M.)

Also Cleaving to the dust by reason of want; having nothing between him and the earth: (IAar, T:) [cleaving to the dust by reason of poverty; see 1:] poor, as though cleaving to the dust: (Msb:) and [simply,] poor: (IAar, T, TA:) or needy, or in want. (M.) [See also mutoribN.]
turobapN: see turaAbN, in seven places.

Also A man's ramos [i. e. his grave: so in the present
day: pl. turbN: or the earth, or dust, thereof]: (M:) or a cemetery, burial-place, or place of graves or of a grave: [so, too, in the present day:] pl. turabN. (Msb.)
tarabapN: see the word next following.
taribapN The end of a finger; i. e. the joint in which is the nail; syn. OanomalapN: (S, K:) pl. taribaAtN. (S.)

Also, (S, M, K,) and tarabapN↓, and tarobaMCu↓, (M, K,) A certain plant, (S, M, K,) growing in the plains, or in soft land, having serrated leaves: or, as some say, a certain thorny tree, of which the fruit is like a suspended unripe date, growing in the plains, or in soft land, and in rugged ground, and in Tihámeh: accord. to AHn, the taribap is a green herb, or leguminous plant, that has a purging effect upon camels: (M:) [accord. to Meyd, as stated by Golius, what is called in Persian xnfj; i. e. the plant thlaspi; and to this it is applied in the present day.]
tarobaMCu: see turaAbN, in five places:
and see taribN:
and taribapN.
turabaMCu: see turaAbN.

tarabuwtN A submissive, or tractable, camel; applied to the male (T, S, M, K) and to the female: (T, S, K:) from turaAbN, (S, M,) because of the abasement thereof; or, as Sb holds it to be, for darabuwtN, by the change of d into t: accord. to Lh, a [camel such as is termed] bakor that is trained, or rendered submissive or tractable; and in like manner a she-camel, one that will follow a person if he takes hold of her lip or her eyelash: and As, who derives it from tNraAbN, says that this epithet is applied to land, or ground, and any other thing, that is caluwl [i.e. easy to walk or ride upon, &c.]. (M.)

turaAbN and turobN↓ (Lth, T, S, M, A, Msb, K) and tarobN↓ (CK [but this I do not find elsewhere]) and turobapF↓ (S, A, * K) and tarobaMCu↓ (Lth, T, S, A, * K) and turabaMCu↓ (S, M, K) and taworaAbN↓ and taworabN↓ and tayoraAbN↓ and tayorabN↓ [and tayrabN↓ as will be seen below] and tariybN↓ (S, M, K) and tiroyabN↓, (M, K) accord. to MF taroyabN↓, which is perhaps a dial. var., and accord. to some tiroyibN↓, and taroyaAbN↓, (TA,) signify the same, (Lth, T, S, M, A, K,) and are words of which the meaning is well known: (A, K:) [i. e. Dust: and earth: generally the former; i. e. fine, dry, particles of earth; as when we say, AlrRiyHu tasuwqu AltRuraAba The wind drives along the dust: but we also use the expression turaAbN nadK, meaning moist earth, the explanation, in Lexicons, of the word varFI:] ?varFI is turaAbN; and when it ceases to be moist, it is still trAb, but is not then called vrI: (Msb voce vrI:) accord. to Fr, turaAbN is a gen. n., from which is formed neither dual nor pl.: and its rel. n. is turaAbiIRN↓: (TA:) [but when it means a kind of dust or earth, as turobapN↓ also does sometimes, it has a pl.: in this case,] accord. to Lh, (M,) its pl. is OatoribapN [a pl. of pauc.] and tirobaAnN [a pl. of mult.]; (S, M, K) and some add turobaAnN: (TA:) [and when turobapN↓ has this, or a similar, meaning, it has for its pl. turabN; as in the phrase OaToyabu AltRurabi the best of the kinds of earth, occurring in this art. in the A:] but no pl. of any of the other syn. words mentioned above has been heard: (M, K:) AAF says that trAb is the pl. of trb; [app. meaning that turaAbN is a quasi-pl. n. (which is often called in lexicons a pl.) of turobN;] but MF observes that this requires consideration: (TA:) Lth says that turobN↓ and turaAbN are syn.; but when the fem. forms of these words are used, they say, OaroDN TayRbapu AltRurobap↓ meaning Land that is good in respect of the natural constitution of its dust or earth; and turaAbapN↓ when meaning A layer, or lamina, of dust or earth, such as is not perceived by the sight, but only by the imagination: (T:) or this last word and turobapN↓ signify a portion of dust or earth: and AlOaroDi turobapu↓ signifies the exterior, or external part, of the earth: (M:) and AltRarobaMCu↓, the earth (S, K) itself. (S.) The Arabs said, AltRuraAbu laka [Dust, or earth, be thy lot]; using the nom. case, although meaning an imprecation, because the word is a simple subst., not an inf. n.: but Lh mentions the phrase AltRuraAba liloOaboEadi [Dust, or earth, be the lot of the remote from good]; saying that the accus. case is used, as though the phrase were an imprecation [of the ordinary kind, in which an inf. n. is used in the accus. case as the absolute complement of its own verb understood]. (M.) And lahu AltRuraAbu is a phrase used as meaning (assumed tropical:) [He has, or shall have, or may he have,] disappointment, (Msb in art. Ehr,) or, nothing. (A 'Obeyd, Mgh in art. frX.) lahu wajanodalFA turobFA↓ is also a form of imprecation, in which substs. in the proper sense of the term are used in the manner of inf. ns., put in the accus. case by reason of a verb unexpressed; as though it were for taribato yadaAhu wajunodilato [May his arms, or his hands, cleave to the dust, or earth, and the stones, by reason of poverty]: and some of the Arabs put the nouns in the nom. case, still using the phrase in the same sense, as though they were in the accus. (M.) One says also, bifiyhi AltRaworabu↓ and AltRayorabu↓ and AltRiyirabu↓ and AltRarobaMCu↓ and AltRaworaAbu↓ [In his mouth is dust, or earth: or may dust, or earth, be in his mouth; i. e. may he die, or be in his grave]. (T.) It is said in a trad. that God created the turobap↓ [meaning the dust, or soil, or, accord. to the TA the earth (OaroD),] on the seventh day of the week; and created upon it the mountains on the first day; and the trees, on the second day. (T.) And one says, laOaDoribanRahu HatRaI yaEaDRa biAltRarobaMCi↓, (Lth, T, A,) meaning [I will assuredly beat him so that he shall bite] the dust, or earth. (Lth, T.) And bayonahumaA maA bayona AljarobaMCi waAltRarobaMCi↓, meaning [Between them two is the space that is between] the heaven and the earth. (A.)
tariybN: see turaAbN:
and see also tariybapN, in two places.
taroyabN: see turaAbN.
taroyabN: see turaAbN.
tiroyibN: see turaAbN.
turaAbapN: see turaAbN.
tariybapN, (S, M, TA,) or tariybN↓, (TA,) sing. of

taraAYibu, (S, M, TA,) which signifies The part of the breast which is the place of the collar, or necklace: (T, M, K:) so by the common consent of the lexicologists: (T:) or the bones of the breast: (M, A, K:) or the bones of the breast that are between the collar-bone and the pap: (S:) or the part of the breast, or chest, that is next to the two collar-bones: or the part that is between the two breasts and the collar-bones: or four ribs of the right side of the chest and four of the left thereof: (M, K:) or the two arms and two legs and two eyes: (T, M, K:) it is also said that the tariybataAni are the two ribs that are next to the two collar-bones: IAth says that the tariybap is the uppermost part of the human breast, beneath the chin; and its pl. is as above: accord. to IF, in the Mj, the tryb↓ is the breast, or chest: MF says that trAYb relates to males and females in common; but most of the authors on strange words affirm decidedly that it is peculiar to women: (TA:) the tariybap of the camel is the part in which it is stabbed, or stuck; syn. manoHar. (M.)
turaAbIRu rel. n. of turaAbN, q. v. (Fr, TA.)
taroyaAbN: see turaAbN.
taworabN: see turaAbN, first sentence, and near the end of the paragraph.
tayorabN: see turaAbN, first sentence, and near the end of the paragraph.
tiyrabN: see turaAbN, first sentence, and near the end of the paragraph.
taworaAbN: see turaAbN, first sentence, and near the end of the paragraph.
tayoraAbN: see turaAbN.
Oatorabu: see what next follows.

mutoribN Possessing much wealth; (T, K;) rich; without want; or having wealth like the dust, or earth: (Lh and M: [in the TA, Atrb is mentioned as having this meaning; perhaps by a mistranscription: if not, it must be Oatorabu↓:]) and having little wealth: thus it bears two contr. significations: (K:) but the former is the more known. (TA.)

matorabapN The suffering loss, and becoming poor, so as to cleave to the dust, or earth; an inf. n. of tariba: (M:) or poverty, or neediness: (S, TA:) [or (as a word of the same class as majobanapu and maboxalapN) a cause of cleaving to the dust, or earth: and hence,] cuwmatorabapK Poor, so as to be cleaving to the dust, or earth: (T:) or [simply] cleaving to the dust, or earth. (S.)
turaAvN: see wariva and wirovN.
turunojN and turunojapN: see what follows.

OutorujRu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the most chaste of the forms here mentioned, (Az, Msb, MF, TA,) a pl., (AHát, MF, TA,) [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] and turunojN↓, (AZ, S, Msb, K, &c.,) [which is Persian,] a dial. var. of weak authority, (Msb,)
by some disallowed, (MF, TA,) used by the vulgar, (TA,) the n in which is by common consent held to be augmentative, (MF, TA,) likewise a pl., (TA,) [or coll. gen. n.,] and OutorunojN↓, mentioned by Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee, in his Faseeh, and also used by the vulgar, (TA,) and by some of the people of Hims, (Lth cited in the L voce HaZRN, q. v.,) [and this is likewise a coll. gen. n.,] and OutorujRapN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) which is the sing. of the first, (AHát, MF, TA,) or its n. un., (L, Msb,) also pronounced OutorujapN, without teshdeed, (TA,) and turunojapN↓, (AZ, S, L, &c.,) likewise a n. un., (L,) A certain fruit, (Msb,) well known, (L, Msb, K,) plentiful in the land of the Arabs, but not growing wild, (L, TA,) [of the species citrus medica, or citron; of which there are two varieties in Egypt; one, of the form of the lemon, but larger, there called turunoj baladiIR; the other, ribbed, and called turunoj muSabRaE: accord. to Golius, citrons of a large size, which have a sweeter peel than others, and are of a size nearly equal to that of a melon:] the sour sort allays the lust of women, clears the complexion, and removes the [discoloration of the face termed] kalaf, (K, TA,) that arises from phlegm; (TA;) the peel thereof, put among clothes, preserves them from the moth-worm: (K, TA:) it is also beneficial as an antidote against the various kinds of poison; the smelling it in times of plague, or pestilence, is beneficial in the highest degree; and jinn, or genii, do not enter the house in which it is; wherefore a reciter of the Kur-án is appropriately likened to it: (TA:) the pl. of OutorujRapN is OutorujRaAtN as well as OutorujRN: [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n., as stated above:] but one should not say turunojaAtN [app. because it is vulgar; for it is agreeable with analogy as pl. of turunojapN; as is also OutorunojaAtN as pl. of OutorunojapN↓]. (AHát, MF, TA.)
OutorunojN and OutorunojapN: see above.

Q. 1. tarojamahu, (S in art. rjm, and Msb and K in the present art.,) and tarojama Eanohu, (K,) inf. n. tarojamapN, (KL,) He interpreted it, (S, Msb, KL, K,) or explained it in another language; (S, Msb, KL;) namely, the speech, or language, (S, Msb, K,) of another person: (Msb:) or, as some say, translated it from one language into another: (TA:) and he explained it; namely, his own speech. (Msb.) [This verb is essentially the same in Arabic, Chaldee, and Ethiopic.]
tarojamahu, inf. n. as above, also signifies He wrote his life; wrote a biography, or biographical notice, of him. (TA, passim; and other works of post-classical times.)
Accord. to the K, the t in this verb is a radical: but see tarojumaAnN, below. (TA.)
tarojamapN [inf. n. of the verb above: used as a simple subst., An interpretation: a translation: pl. taraAjimu.
Also] A life, or biography, or biographical notice, of any person: pl. as above. (TA, passim; and other works of post-classical times.)
And An article, a head, chapter, section, or paragraph, of a book. (TA, passim; and other works of post-classical times.)

tarojumaAnN and turojumaAnN and tarojamaAnN, (S in art. rjm, and Msb and K in the present art.,) of which three dial. vars. the first is the best, (Msb,) and is that which commonly obtains, (TA,) An interpreter; (S, Msb, K;) an explainer of speech in another language: (S, Msb:) [a translator: (see the verb, above:)] pl. taraAjimu and taraAjimapN; which latter favours the opinion of those who hold the word to be of foreign origin. (S, Msb.) The t and m are [said to be] radicals; but J makes the t to be augmentative, and trjmAn is mentioned in the T [as well as in the S] in art. rjm, though the author of the T has mentioned the verb among quadriliteral-radical words; and there is a reason [for deriving it from rajama], for one says lisaAnN yarojumu meaning “ a tongue that is chaste, or perspicuous, and copious, in speech: ” most, however, hold the t to be a radical. (Msb.) It is said in the K that the verb shows the t to be radical; whereas J and AHei and IKt hold it to be augmentative; but there is a difference of opinion whether it be from AlrRajomu biAlHijaArapi [the throwing stones], or from AlrRajomu biAlgayobi [the conjecturing, or speaking conjecturally]; and also whether it be Arabic, or arabicized from drgmAn [a word which I do not know in Persian nor in any other language]: (MF, TA:) if arabicized, the present is its proper place. (TA.)
mutarojamN [Interpreted: or translated.
And also The subject of a biography, or biographical notice.
And] (assumed tropical:) Confused, or dubious. (Har p. 537.)

1. tariHa, aor.
taraHa
, inf. n. taraHN, He grieved; he was, or became, sorrowful, unhappy, or anxious; (Msb, K;) syn. Hazina; (Msb;) [contr. of fariHa; (see taraHN, below;)] as also ttrRH↓. (K.)
[Also He perished, or died: became cut off; was put an end to; or came to an end: so accord. to explanations of taraHN given below on the authority of IAth.]

2. trRHhu, (S, A, K,) inf. n. tatoriyHN; (S, K;) and AtrHhu↓; (A, Msb;) It (an affair, or an event, &c., TA,) grieved him; it made him sorrowful, unhappy, or anxious. (S, A, Msb, K.) A poet cited by IAar says,
[Long did that which made unhappy make her, or them, unhappy]; meaning that the pasturage rendered troublesome her, or their, state. (Th, AZ, TA.)
4: see 2.
5: see 1.
taroHN Poverty; need; indigence. (K.)

taraHN Grief, sorrow, unhappiness, or anxiety; syn. HuzonN, (Msb,) or hamRN, (K,) or gamRN; (Har p. 141;) contr. of faraHN. (S, A.) [It is the inf. n. of 1; but used as a subst., it has a pl., namely, OatoraAHN, like OaforaAHN. Hence the saying,] maA AldRunoyaA UilRaA faraHN wataraHN [The present world, or life, is nothing but a scene, or state, of joy and grief]. (A.)
A perishing, or dying: becoming cut off; being put an end to; or coming to an end. (IAth, TA.)

A descending, going down, or going down a declivity; syn. hubuwTN. (Ibn-Munádhir, K.) One says, maA zilonaA mucu AlRayolapi fiI taraHK i. e. [We have not ceased from the beginning of this night to be] in a state of descending, &c. (Ibn-Munádhir.)
tariHN Grieving; sorrowing; unhappy. (Msb.)
A man (A) who possesses, or does, little, or no, good, (A, K,) so that he who asks of him grieves. (A.)
taroHapN A grief; a sorrow; an unhappiness. (L.) [Hence the saying,] maAmino faraHaho UilRaA wabaEodahaA taroHaho [There is no joy but there is after it a grief]. (A.)
mutoriHN, or mutoraHN, accord. to different copies of the K, (TA,) One who ceases not to hear and see that which does not please him. (K.)

[matoraHapN A cause of grief, sorrow, unhappiness, or anxiety: pl. mataAriHu. Hence the saying,] tarRaHatohu AlmataAriHu [Misfortunes (lit. the causes of grief, &c.,) grieved him, or made him sorrowful, &c.]. (A.)
mutarRaHN Strait, difficult, or distressful, life. (A, K.)
A scanty torrent, or flow of water, in which is a stopping, or an interruption. (K.)
A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed so as to be saturated with the dye. (Az, K.)
matoraAHN A she-camel whose milk soon comes to an end, or stops: (S, L:) pl. mataAriyHu. (L.)

1. tarasa AlbaAba, aor.
tarusa
, inf. n. tarosN, He fastened, or closed, the door [with a bar or] in any manner. (TA.)
2. trRs, inf. n. tatoriysN, He made a person to arm himself with a shield. (KL.)
See also 5.

5. ttrRs, (S, A, K,) or ttrRs biturosK, (M,) He defended himself with a turos [or shield]; (S, M, A, * K;) as also trRs↓, inf. n. tatoriysN; (S, K;) and AitRarasa↓, (Sb, M, A, TA,) inf. n. AitRiraAsN, of the measure AifotiEaAlN: (TA:) and ttrRs biXaIoCK he made a thing to be as a turos; he defended, or protected, himself with it. (Msb.) You say also, tasatRarotu bika mina AlHadavaAni fatatarRasotu mino nibaAli AlzRamaAni (tropical:) [I protected myself by thee from calamities, and so shielded myself from the arrows of fortune]. (A.) And OaxacatN UibiliI silaAHahaA watatarRasato biturosihaA, meaning (tropical:) My camels became fat and goodly, and prevented their owner from slaughtering them. (A, TA.) [See silaAHN.]
8: see 5.

turosN [A shield;] a certain piece of defensive
armour; (M, TA;) a thing well known: (A, Msb, K:) pl. tirasapN and tiraAsN (S, M, Msb, K) and tiraAsapN (S) and turuwsN, [all pls. of mult.,] and OatoraAsN, [a pl. of pauc.,] (S, M, Msb, K,) but not OatorisapN. (ISk, S, Msb.) A turos that is made of skins, without wood and without sinews in it, is called HajafapN and daraqapN. (Msb.)
Also (tropical:) The disk of the sun. (A, * TA.)
And (tropical:) A smooth, round, level piece of ground: (A, TA:) or a rugged piece of hard, or hard and level, ground. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)
See also matarosN.
tiraAsapN The art of making shields. (K.)
tarRaAsN A man having a shield; (S, M, A, K;) as also taArisN↓. (S, A.)
And A maker of shields. (K.)
taArisN: see tarRaAsN.

matarosN; so accord. to El-Háfidh Ibn-Hajar, and this is the correct form; written in the T and the Towsheeh matRarosN; and by some, matorasN [as in the CK]; and by some, matorasN [as I find it in two copies of the S and in a copy of the K]; (TA;) [A wooden door-bar;] a piece of wood that is put behind the door; (S, K) the XijaAr [or wooden bar] that is put against the door as a stay: (T, L, TA:) [mataroso is] a Persian word, [having the above-mentioned signification, but originally a contraction of maho taroso, and] meaning “ fear not thou,” with it [being here understood]: (T, K, TA:) or the name of this piece of wood in Arabic is turosN↓: (M, TA:) which also signifies a piece of wood with which a couch-frame (sariyr) is repaired, by its being affixed as a DabRap: (M:) [and the Arabic word XijaArN has this latter signification also:] the Persian word is mataroso. (M, TA.)
Their saying mataros, with fet-h to the m and t, and sukoon to the r means [also] Security [is given] to thee, therefore fear thou not: it is said to be Persian. (Msb.)

matorasapN, (M, A,) or mtorasapN, (K, accord. to the TA, [and so I find in a MS. copy of that work, and in the CK, but the former is probably the correct form, being agreeable with analogy, like maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.,]) Anything by which one is defended, or protected. (M, Msb, K.) You say also huwa matorasapN laka (tropical:) [He is a cause of defence, or protection, to thee]. (A.)
baAbN matoruwsN A door fastened, or closed, [with a bar, or] in any manner. (TA.)

1. tariEa, aor.
taraEa
, inf. n. taraEN, It (a vessel, S, or a thing, TA) was, or became, full, or filled; (S, Z, K;) as also AitRaraEa↓: (Sgh, K:) or it was, or became, very full, or much filled. (Lth, in TA. [But it is said in the TA, in one place, that Lth ignored the verb in this sense; and in another place, that he said, I have not heard them say, tariEa AlUinaMCu.])

He hastened to do evil, or mischief; (Ks, K;) and to do a thing: (TA:) and bahi UilaI AlXRarRi ttrRE↓, accord. to the K; but accord. to the S and O and L, ttrRE↓ Uilayohi biAlXRarRi; (TA;) he hastened to him to do evil, or mischief. (S, O, L, K.)
He rushed headlong into affairs by reason of excessive briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (Lth, K.)
taraEahu, inf. n. taraEN, [app. a mistake for taroEN,] He hastened to him, forbidding [him to do a thiug]. (L.)
taraEahu Eano wajohihi He averted him, or turned him back, from his course, or manner of acting or proceeding. (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, L, K.)

2. trRE AlbaAba, inf. n. tatoriyEN, He locked, or closed, the door; syn. Oagolaqahu [which has both these significations]. (K.) In the Kur [xii. 23], some read, watarRaEati AlOabowAba And she locked, or closed, the doors, instead of galRaqat. (O, TA.)
4. AtrEhu He filled it; (S, K;) namely, a. vessel. (S.)
5: see 1, in two places.
8: see 1.
taraEN Full; applied to a watering-trough or tank for beasts &c.; (S, K;) and to a mug: (S:) an inf. n. used as an epithet: (TA:) the regular form is tariEN↓, which signifies the same. (K.)
tariEN: see taraEN.
Also A cloud containing much rain. (TA.)
EuXobN tariEN Fresh, juicy, or sappy, herbs or herbage. (Sgh in art. drE, and L.)

A man quick to do evil, or mischief, (Ks, S,) and to become angry: (S:) ready and quick to become angry: and mutotariEN↓ evil, or mischievous, hastening to do what is not fit, or proper, for him. (TA.)
One who rushes headlong into affairs by reason of excessive briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (O, L, TA:) thus correctly written; but in the copies of the K, tariyEN↓. (TA.)
Lightwitted; weak and stupid; deficient in intellect; or light and hasty in disposition or deportment. (TA.)
And, with p, A woman who transgresses the proper bounds or limits, and is light [in conduct]. (TA.)

turoEapN The mouth of a streamlet or rivulet; (IB, Msb, K;) i. e. a place hollowed out by the water in the side of a river, whence it flows forth: (Msb:) pl. turaEN (IB, Msb) and turoEaAtN and turaEaAtN and turuEaAtN: (Msb:) in the S it is said to signify the mouths of streamlets or rivulets; but correctly the sentence should be, turaEN is pl. of turoEapN, and has this signification. (IB.)

A canal, or channel of water, to a meadow or garden or the like: (L, TA:) this is the meaning commonly known [in the present day: the general name in Egypt for a canal cut for the purpose of irrigation, conveying the water of the Nile through the adjacent fields]. (TA.)

The opening, or gap, of a wateringtrough or tank, by which the water enters, and where the people draw it: (Az, Mgh, * K, * TA:) and, (K,) accord. to AA, (TA,) the station of the drinkers at the watering-trough or tank; as in the O and K; or, as in the L, the part of the watering-trough or tank which is the station of the drinkers. (TA.)
A meadow, or garden, or the like, (S, K,) in an elevated place: (K:) if in low land, it is called rawoDapN. (TA.)

A stair; or a flight of steps by which one ascends; syn. darajapN: (S, K:) so accord. to some in a trad., which see in what follows: (S, * TA:) and particularly the flight of steps of a pulpit. (AA, Sgh, K.)

(tropical:) A door, or gate: (S, Sgh, Msb, K:) pl. turaEN. (K.) You say, fataHa turoEapa AldRaAri (tropical:) He opened the door of the house. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., UinRa minobariy hecaA EalaI turoEapK mino turaEi AljanRapi, (S, TA,) as though meaning, (tropical:) Verily this my pulpit is at a gate of the gates of Paradise: thus explained by Sahl Ibn-Saad Es-Sá'idee, the relater of the trad.; and A'Obeyd says, wahuwa Alwajohu [“ and it is the proper, ” or “ the valid and obvious, way, ” of explaining it], meaning that it is the preferable explanation: but the author of the K, mistaking his meaning, makes wajohN to be another signification of turoEapN: or the meaning of this trad. is, he who acts according to the exhortations recited upon the steps of my pulpit will enter Paradise: or, accord. to Kt, prayer and praise in this place are means of attaining to Paradise; so that it is as though it were a portion of Paradise. (TA.) In the same manner Sahl explained his other trad,, UinRa qadamiI EalaI turoEapK mino turaEi AlHawoDi (tropical:) [Verily my foot is at a gate of the gates of the pool of Paradise]. (TA.)
tariyEN: see tariEN.

tarRaAEN A torrent filling the valley; as also OatoraEu↓: (K:) or a torrent which fills the valley: (S:) and ↓the latter, a vehement torrent. (TA.) J says, in the S, that sayorN OanozaEu↓ signifies XadiydN; and he cites the words of a poet thus:

ascribed by some to El-'Ajjáj, but correctly, accord. to IB, the words of Ru-beh; making two mistakes, in saying AftrX, in the sing., and bsyr: moreover, the last word in the citation is a pret. verb: [the right reading is]

[And they travelled the land with a multitude like a torrent that filled the valleys]: the poet describes the Benoo-Temeem, and their travelling the land like the torrent by reason of multitude. (Sgh, TA.)
(assumed tropical:) A door-keeper. (Th, S, K.)
OatoraEu: see tarRaAEN, in three places.
HawoDN mutoraEN A filled watering-trough or tank: (TA:) and jafonapN mutoraEapN a filled bowl. (S.)
munotariEN: see tariEN.

1. tarifa, aor.
tarafa
, (Sgh, K,) inf. n. tarafN, (M, TA,) He enjoyed, or led, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty; (M, Sgh, K;) as also ttrRf↓. (K.)
And the former verb, (assumed tropical:) It (a plant, or herbage,) was, or became, luxuriant, flourishing, succulent, or sappy; or bright and fresh, by reason of plentiful irrigation. (M, TA.)
2: see 4, in two places.

tatoriyfN [app. as the inf. n. of the pass. verb, turRifa, also signifies] Good
feeding. (M.)
And trRf AlrRajula, and Atrfhu↓, He rendered the man submissive; or made him to submit: and he made the man king, or prince: [in both senses] like rafRalahu. (M.)

4. Oatorafatohu AlnRiEomapN [Wealth, or what God bestowed upon him,] made him to behave exorbitantly; to be excessively disobedient or rebellious; to exalt himself, and be inordinate in infidelity; or to be extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing: (S, K:) and so saEapu AlEayoXi [plentifulness and easiness of life]: and in like manner, tarRafatohu↓ it caused him to exult, or to exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TA.) And [Wealth, or what God bestowed upon him,] made him to enjoy, or lead, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty; as also tarRafatohu↓. (K.)
Atrf AlrRajula He gave the man the object of his eager desire; or of his yearning, or longing, or appetency. (Lh, M.)
See also 2.
Atrf also signifies He persevered in, or persisted in, or resolved upon, transgression, wrongdoing, or deviation from the right way. (El-'Ozeyzee, K.)
5: see 1.

10. Asttrf He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently: he behaved exorbitantly; was excessively disobedient or rebel-lious; exalted himself, and was inordinate in infidelity; or was extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing. (Z, Sgh, K.)

turofapN Plentifulness, and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life; a life of softness or delicacy, and ease, comfort, or affluence; or ease and plenty; syn. naEomapN, (T, K, TA,) and saEapu AlEayoXi: (TA:) or i. q. niEomapN [i. e. wealth; or what God bestows upon one; &c.]. (Mgh, and so in the CK. [But this I think a mistranscription, for naEomp.])
Good, sweet, or pleasant, food. (IDrd, M, K.)

A new, or strange, thing, (XaIoCN TariyfN, [in some copies of the K, Zariyf is put in the place of Tariyf,]) that one appropriates, or peculiarly assigns, [as a gift] to a friend; or by [the gift of] which one distinguishes a friend: (K:) any Turofap [i. e. gift not given to any one before; or of which the recipient did not possess the like, and which pleases him; or novel, or rare, and pleasing, present]. (M, TA.)
A thing protuberant in the middle of the upper lip, by nature. (Lth, * T, * S, M, K.)
A misoqaAp [q. v.] with which one drinks. (M, TA.)
Oatorafu Having a natural protuberance in the middle of his upper lip, called turofap. (Lth, * T, * M, K.)
mutorafN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.] One left to do what he will; not prevented from doing so. (Ibn- 'Arafeh, K.)

And hence, (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA,) One enjoying, or leading, a plentiful; and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty: (Ibn-'Arafeh, M, K, TA:) luxurious, or indulging himself largely in the pleasures, or delights, of the present life, and in its appetites, or eager desires: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) one who is not prevented from enjoying himself: (K, TA:) and one whose means of subsistence are made ample, or plentiful; as also mutarRafN↓: (M:) one whom plentifulness, and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life, or whom a life of ease and plenty, (T,) or whom wealth, or what God has bestowed upon him, and plentifulness and easiness of life, (Mgh,) causes to exult, or to exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (T, Mgh:) and i. q. jabRaArN [i. e. one who magnifies himself; or behaves proudly, haughtily, or insolently; &c.]: (K:) so says Katádeh, in explaining the phrase OamaronaA mutorafiyhaA, in the Kur [xvii. 17: see Oamara]: or, accord. to some, mtrfyhA here means the worst of its chiefs; and the leaders in evil. (TA.)
Also, (TA,) or mutarRafN↓, (T,) A boy made soft, or delicate, in body, and rendered submissive. (T, TA.)
mutarRafN: see mutorafN, in two places.
Q. Q. 1. taroqayotuhu, (ISk, JK, S, K,) inf. n. taroqaApN, (ISk, S, K,) I hit, or hurt, his (a man's, ISk, JK, S) taroquwap [or collar-bone]. (ISk, JK, S, K.)

taroquwapN The collar-bone; the bone between the pit at the uppermost part of the chest and the shoulder, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) on either side, connecting those two parts, (JK, Mgh,) of a man &c.; (TA;) each of the two prominent bones in the uppermost part of the chest, from the head of each shoulder to the edge of the pit above mentioned: (TA in art. trb:) [and sometimes, as in a phrase which see below,] the fore part of the Haloq [here app. meaning the throat], at the uppermost part of the chest, the place into which the soul [for AlnRafasu, in copies of the K, I read AlnRafosu] rises [when one is at the point of death]: (K in art. rqw:) pl. trAqK (JK, Mgh, K) and trAYiq; (JK, K;) the latter formed by transposition: (JK:) Fr says that the latter pl. is used by some for the former: (TA:) the sing. is of the measure faEoluwapN, (JK, S, K,) as is shown by the verb mentioned above, (K,) though it is repeated in the K in art. rqw: (TA:) one should not say turoquwapN, with damm to the t. (S K.) UicaA balagati AltRaraAqiIa, in the Kur lxxv. 26, means When it (the soul) reaches the uppermost parts of the chest; [or, the parts of the throat next the chest;] for AlnRafosu is understood: (Bd:) said when one is at the point of death. (TA.)

tiroyaAqN, an arabicized word, (S, Msb, K,) from the Greek, (Msb, K,) [i. e. from θηριακὰ,] or originally Persian, (S, O,) also written and pronounced diroyaAqN, (JK, Msb,) and TiroyaAqN; (Msb;) or, as some say, from AlrRiyqu, because containing the spittle of serpents, and, if so, it is Arabic [in origin]: (Msb:) [Theriac; also called treacle;] an antidote for poisons; (S, O;) a certain compound medicine, (K,) comprising many ingredients, at most ninety or ninety-six, and at least sixty-four, (TA,) sometimes including the flesh of vipers, (K, TA,) and that of asses, which cause it to be prohibited and impure, or, as some say, it is prohibited without restriction: (TA:) it is a remedy against the bite or sting of rapacious venomous reptiles and the like, and poisonous potions: (K: [I omit some unprofitable and absurd particulars respecting the compounds thus termed, in the K and other lexicons &c.:]) pl. taraAyiyqu. (K in art. frq.) The best kind is called AltRiroyaAqu AlfaAruwqu, (K in art. frq,) vulgarly tiroyaAqN faAruwqiIRN. (TA in that art.) [A principal ingredient of this kind is the best sort of Jews-pitch, i. e. asphaltum, also called mumia, and in Arabic muwmiyaA:) (see De Sacy's “ Rel. de l'Égypte par Abdallatif, ” ” p. 274:) and this mumia, by itself, is called AltRiroyaAqu AltRurokiIRu.]
[It is sometimes applied to Treacle, as meaning the sirop that drains from sugar.] It is also said to be applied to the faAdozahor [or Bezoar-stone], likewise termed masuwsN. (TA in art. ms.)

Also, and tiroyaAqapN↓, (assumed tropical:) Wine; (S, O, K;) because it dispels anxiety; (S;) or because it is a remedy for anxieties; (O;) wherefore it is also termed SaAbuwnu Alhumuwmi. (TA.) tiroyaAqapN: see the last sentence above. [baAcinojaAnu tiroyaAqiIRN Zanthium.]

1. tarakahu, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
taruka
, (S, M,) inf. n. tarokN (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and trokaAnN, with kesr, (Fr, K,) He left it, forsook it, relinquished it, abandoned it, deserted it, or quitted it; either intentionally, and by choice, or by constraint, and of necessity: (Er-Rághib, TA:) he left it, forsook it, &c., as above; namely, a thing that he desired, or wished for, and also a thing that he did not desire, or did not wish for: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) he left it, quitted it, went away from it, or departed from it; namely, a place: and he left him, forsook him, relinquished him, abandoned him, deserted him, quitted him, or separated himself from him: (Msb:) he cast it, or threw it, away, as a thing of no account; rejected it; discarded it; cast it off; left it off: (MF, TA:) he left it, left it alone, let it alone; ceased, desisted, forbore, or abstained, from it; neglected it, omitted it, or left it undone; syn. xalRaAhu; (S, A, O;) or wadaEahu; (M, K;) as also AtRrkhu↓. (K. [But respecting this latter verb, see what follows.]) waQtoruki AlbaHora rahowFA, in the Kur xliv. 23, And leave thou the sea opened with a wide interval; or motionless, in the same state as before thy passing through it, and strike it not with thy rod, nor alter anything thereof; (Bd;) or motionless, parted asunder; (Jel;) so that the Egyptians may enter it; (Bd, Jel;) is an instance of the verb meaning leaving intentionally, and by choice: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and kamo tarakuwA mino janRaAtK waEuyuwnK, in the next verse, How many gardens and springs did they leave! (Jel,) is an instance of the verb meaning leaving by constraint, and of necessity. (Er-Rághib, TA.) In a phrase such as taraka HaqRahu, meaning He made his right, or due, or claim, to be null, or he rejected it, and such as taraka rakoEapN mina AlSRalaApi, meaning He neglected, omitted, or left unperformed, a
rkEp, of the prayer, [it is said (but I think it doubtful) that] the verb, having an ideal substantive for its objective complement, is used metaphorically. (Msb.) qaAla fiyhi famaA QtRaraka↓ means maA taraka XayoYFA [i. e. He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, (Aijotahada,) in it, and neglected not, or omitted not, anything in his power]: the verb is of the measure AifotaEala. (S.) mano OawoSaI biAlvRuluvi walamo XayoYFA yatRariko↓ is a mistake for wlm yatoruko XayoYFA, or wlm yatRariko↓ without XayoYFA, or famaA QtRaraka; for this verb is not trans., except, sometimes, in poetry; and the meaning is, walamo yatoruko fiymaAOucina lahu fiyhi XayoYFA [i. e. He who bequeaths the third of his property, and does not omit anything of what he is allowed (to leave, or anything of the third part, for this is all that he is allowed to bequeath)]: it is from the saying faEala famaA QtRaraka↓ [He did such a thing, and neglected not, or omitted not, anything]. (Mgh.) You say also, taraka AlmayRitu maAlFA, i. e. The deceased left property. (Msb.)

watarakonaA Ealayohi fiI AlMxiriyna, (K,) in the Kur [xxxvii. 76 &c.], (TA,) means And we have perpetuated (K, Jel, TA) to him a eulogy among the later generations (Jel, TA) of the prophets and peoples to the day of resurrection, [namely,] Salutation &c. (Jel.)

AltRaroku is also syn. with AljaEolu, (Lth, K, TA,) in some instances; (Lth, TA;) as though it had two contr. significations: (K:) [i. e.,] when taraka is doubly trans., it has the meaning of SayRara, (MF, TA,) or jaEala. (TA.) So in the saying, tarakotu AlHabola XadiydFA I made, or rendered, the rope strong; or made it, or caused it, to be, or become, strong. (TA.) So too in the Kur ii. 16, watarakahumo fiI ZulumaAtK And maketh, or causeth, them to be in darknesses. (Ksh, Bd, MF.) And sometimes one says of any action that has come at last to a certain state, maA tarakotuhu kacaA [I did not make it, or cause it, to be thus]. (TA.)

tarika, aor.
taraka
, (IAar, K,) inf. n. tarokN, (TK,) He (a man, IAar) married, i. e. took to wife, a tariykap, (IAar, K,) meaning a woman that had remained a virgin, unmarried, until she had become of middle age, or long after she had attained to puberty, in the house, or tent, of her parents. (TA.)

3. tArkhu [inf. n. mutaArakapN] is syn. with xaAlaAhu (S in art. xlw) [which is explained in the K, in art. xlw, as syn. with tarakahu, He left, forsook, relinquished, abandoned, &c., him or it; and thus it may often be well rendered: but it properly signifies he left him, forsook him, &c., being left, &c., by him; whence it is said in the Mgh, in art. wdE, that muwaAdaEapu is syn. with muSaAlaHapN because it is mutaArakapN: Golius, as on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, explains tArkhu as signifying he dismissed him, and did not molest him: he left him unmolested is one of its meanings, but is not the primary signification: accord. to the TK, mtArkp signifies the leaving, &c., anything in the state in which it is: and the leaving, &c., one another]. One says also, taArakotuhu AlbayoEa, (S, Mgh, but in the latter taArakahu, and in the TA fiI AlbayoEi,) wagayorahu, (Mgh,) inf. n. mutaArakapN, (S,) [app. meaning I relinquished with him, i. e. concurrently with him, the sale, &c.: see 6, by which this rendering is confirmed: Golius, as on the authority of J, who has not explained it, says that it means I relinquished to him the merchandise, or commodity; and Freytag follows him.]
[Hence,] mutaArakapN is metonymically used as meaning The making peace [or a truce], or reconciling oneself, with another or others. (Mgh.)

In the saying, laA baAraka QllRehu fiyihi walaA taAraka walaA daAraka, it is an imitative sequent, (K,) all of these verbs having the same meaning [so that the saying may be rendered May God not bless him nor felicitate him nor make him happy]: (TA:) [or the meaning may be, nor preserve him, or prolong his life; for] IAar says that taAraka means OaboqaI. (TA.)
6. tataArakuwA AlOamora bayonahumo, (K,) or AlOamora fiymaA bayonahumo, (Mgh,) They relinquished [concurrently], one with another, the affair that was between them. (TK.)
8. AitRaraka: see 1, in five places.
tarokN: see tariykapN.
Also A [drinking-cup or bowl such as is called] qadaH which a man lifts, or carries, with his two hands. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

AltRuroku A certain nation; (S, Msb, K;) [namely, the Turks:] turokiIRN is its n. un.: (Msb, TA:) [and signifies also Turkish:] pl. OatoraAkN. (Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., AutorukuwA AltRaroka maA tarakuw kumo [Leave ye alone the Turks as long as they leave you alone]. (TA.) [turokiIRu Alwajohi often occurs in post-classical works as meaning Having a Turkish face; i. e. round-faced, or broad-faced; opposed to EarabiIRu Alwajohi.]
tarokapN: see tariykapN, in two places.
Also (assumed tropical:) A woman such as is termed raboEapN [i. e. of middling stature]: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) pl. tarokaAtN. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., jaMCa Alxaliylu UilaI makRapa yuTaAliEu tarokatahu (assumed tropical:) [El-Khaleel (i. e. Abraham) came to Mekkeh to get knowledge of his trkp], meaning Hagar, and her son Ishmael: (K:) the word originally means an ostrich's egg, and is here used metaphorically; for the ostrich lays but one egg in the year, and then leaves it and goes away: (TA:) Z says, in the Fáïk, that it is thus related, with the r quiescent; (Nh, O, TA;) but it would be a proper way if it were with kesr to the r [tarikatahu↓,] as meaning the thing that he had left, or forsaken, &c. (Nh, O, K.)
tirokapN: see what next follows.

tarikapN A thing that is left, forsaken, relinquished, abandoned, deserted, or quitted; like TalibapN meaning “ a thing desired, or sought; ” (TA;) see also tarokapN: particularly, the inheritance, or property that is left, of a person deceased; (S, Msb, K; *) also pronounced tirokapN↓: pl. tarikaAtN. (Msb.)

taraAki an imperative verbal noun, meaning Autoruko [Leave thou, &c.]. (S, TA.) Hence the saying, taraAki taraAki SuHobapa AlOatoraAki [Leave thou, leave thou, the companionship of the Turks]. (TA.) Yoo says that taraAka is a dial. var. of the same; but this is only when it is used as a prefixed noun, as in taraAkahaA for taraAkihaA. (TA.)
tariykN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

tariykapN A woman that is left unmarried; (S, K;) that has remained a virgin, unmarried, until she has become of middle age, or long after she has attained to puberty, in the house, or tent, of her parents: (TA:) it is not applied to a male: (Lh, TA:) pl. taraAYiku. (S.)

A meadow the depasturing of which has been neglected: (S, K:) or a pasture-land where people have pastured their beasts, either in a desert or upon a mountain, and of which the beasts have eaten until there remain [only] some relics of wood. (TA.)
Water left by a torrent: (IB, K:) used in this sense by El-Farezdak. (IB.)

An egg after the young bird has gone forth from it: (K:) or an ostrich's egg (S, K) which she forsakes (S, TA) in the desert after it has become empty: (TA:) or, as some say, an ostrich's eggs left solitary: (TA:) and tarokapN↓ signifies the same. (K.) [For the pl., see the next sentence.]

(assumed tropical:) An iron helmet; (K;) in the opinion of ISd, as being likened to the egg thus termed; (TA;) and so tarokapN↓: (S, K:) the pl. [of the former] is taraAYiku [mentioned in the S as pl. of the former applied to an ostrich's egg] and tariykN↓ and tarokN↓ [the latter of which is termed in the S pl. of tarokapN are coll. gen. ns. of which tariykapN and tarokapN are the ns. un.]. (K.)

A raceme of dates (kibaAsap [in the CK, erroneously, kunAsp]) after it has had what was upon it shaken off, (AHn, K, TA,) and is left: pl. taraAYiku: (AHn, TA:) and tariykN↓ signifies a raceme (EunoqNwd) when what was upon it has been eaten; (AHn, K, TA;) and a raceme of dates (Eicoq) that has had what was upon it shaken off, (K, TA,) so that nothing remains upon it: so AHn says in one place. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., UinRa lilRhi taraAYika fiI xaloqihi, meaning [Verily to God are referrible] conditions which He hath perpetuated in mankind, of hope and heedlessness, so that they apply themselves thereby with boldness, forwardness, presumptuousness, or arrogance, to the things of the present world. (TA.)
matoruwkN [pass. part. n. of taraka, Left, forsaken, &c.
] In lexicology, Obsolete. (Mz 10th nwE.)

trmA [The Turkumán;] a certain people, or race, of the Turks; [absurdly said to be] so called because two hundred thousand of them became believers in one month; wherefore they said laA taramaA [the Turks of belief]; which was afterwards contracted into turokumaAnN: (K, TA:) [a coll. gen. n.: n. un., and rel. n., turokumaAniIRN:] pl. taraAkimapN. (TA.)
laA taramaA i. q. lA siyRamaA [which see in art. swy]. (K.)

turomusN [vulgarly pronounced in the present day tiromis; from the Greek θέρμος, or Coptic θαρος; Lupines; or the lupine;] a certain grain, well known, of the description termed qaTaAniIR; (Msb;) the produce of a tree [or plant] which has a grain ribbed and notched: (Lth, M, * K:) or i. q. baAqilRaI miSoriIRN: (the Minháj and K:) [but if this be the same as the baAqilRaI qiboTiIR, it is a mistake, accord. to Ibn-Beytár, to identify it with the trms:] AHn says that it is the jirojiyr miSoriIR, and is of the description termed qaTaAniIR; and under the head of the letter j, he says that the jirojiyr is the baAqilRiI: accord. to the Minháj, it is a grain of an expanded shape, of bitter taste, hollowed in the middle; and the wild kind is smaller than the other, and stronger: and the trms approaches more to medicine than to food: the best is the white, large, and heavy: (TA:) some say that the t is augmentative, and that the word is from ramasa, signifying “ he concealed ” a thing: (MF, TA:) the n. un. is with p (Msb.)

turonaI an appellation applied to A female slave; (T, K) and to a fornicatress, an adulteress, or a prostitute; (M, K;) as also farotanaI: (T, K:) and Aibonu turonaI means the son of a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute; (T, K;) as also Abn farotanaI: (T:) or one that is base-born: (S in art. rnw:) but it is said that turonaI is of the measure tufEalu, from AlrRunuwRu: (M:) it may be from runiyato meaning “ she was looked at continuously. ” (T, K.)
turunojN and turunojapN: see art. trj.
OutorunojN and OutorunojapN: see art. trj.

taranojubiynN and taranojabiynN and turanojabiynN [thus variously written, in the last manner in the TA, and there said to be “ with damm; ” from the Persian taranoGubiyno; A kind of manna; the manna of the thorny plant called by the Arabs the HaAj, and hence by European botanists “ alhagi: ” accord. to Dr. Royle (art. “ Man ” in Kitto's Cycl. of Bibl. Lit.), it is a sweetish juice which exudes from the alhagi maurorum, concretes into small granular masses, and is usually distinguished by the name of Persian manna: he also states that the alhagi maurorum and another species, alhagi desertorum, are ‘ called in Mesopotamia “ agool, ” according to some authorities, while by others this is thought to be the name of another plant: ’ by “ agool ” is meant EaAquwl, q. v.:] a kind of dew (TalRN), that falls mostly in Khurásán and in Ma-waráli-n-nahr, and, in our country, mostly upon the HAj: the best thereof is that which is fresh, or moist, and white: (Ibn-Seenà, or “ Avicenna, ” vol. i. of the Arabic ed., p. 262:) the manR [or manna] mentioned in the Kur-án [ii. 54]. (Ksh, Bd, Jel, TA.) [See also “ Ibn Baithar ” (Ibn-Beytár), vol. i. p. 207.]

1. tariha, aor.
taraha
, He fell into what are termed turRahaAt, said to signify, originally, [deserts, such as are termed] qifaAr, and to be metaphorically applied to (tropical:) false, or vain, sayings or actions or affairs; unprofitable sayings: (K, * TA:) or (assumed tropical:) he uttered false and confused and vain speech, with somewhat of embellishment, (Lth, TA,) or without foundation, or order, or method. (Akh, TA.)
turRahN: see what next follows, in two places.
turRahapN A small road branching off from a main road: (As, S, K:) a Persian word, arabicized: (As, S:) pl. turRahaAtN (As, S, K) and turRuhaAtN. (TA.)
A [desert, such as is termed qaforN, (see 1,) or] mafaAzapN, and SaHoraMCu. (JK.)

The first in this paragraph is the primary signification: (TA:) and hence, metaphorically, (As, S,) (tropical:) A false, or vain, saying or action or affair; (As, JK, S K;) as also turRahN↓: (S, K:) pl. of the former, turRahaAtN (JK, S, K *) [and turRuhaAtN, as above]; and of the latter, taraAriyahu: (S, K: *) or the primary signification of turRahaAtN is qifaArN: [see 1:] and it is metaphorically applied to (tropical:) false, or vain, sayings or actions or affairs; (K;) and unprofitable sayings: (Z, K, TA:) or, accord. to Az, false, or vain, affairs: and the sing. is turRahN↓: or, accord. to IB, this last is pl. of turRahapN: [or rather a coll. gen. n.:] or, as some say, it is a sing.: (TA:) and accord. to Lth it signifies the act of lying, and confusing [truth and falsehood]. (Har p. 165.) [Sometimes it is followed by a syn., to give greater force to the signification:] one says AlturRahaAtu AlbasaAbisu and AlturRahaAtu AlSRaHaASiHu: and sometimes the former word is used as a prefixed noun governing the gen. case [so that one says turRahaAtu AlbasaAbisu and trRhAtu AlSRaHaASiHi: AlSRaHoSaHu is mentioned in the K, in this art., as a syn. of AltRurRahapu]. (S.)
Also A calamity; a misfortune; an evil accident: (JK, * K:) pl. [turRahaAtN and] taraAriyahu. (JK.)
Wind. (JK, K.)
Clouds, or a collection of clouds. (JK, * K.)
A certain small creeping thing (duwayobRap) [found] in the sand. (JK, K.)

1. tasaEahumo, aor.
tasaEa
(S, Msb, K) and
tasiEa
(Yoo, Msb, K) and
tasuEa
, (Msb,) inf. n. tasoEN, (T K,) He took the ninth part of their possessions: or he became the ninth of them: (S, Msb, K:) or he made them to be nine with himself; (K;) they having before been eight. (TA.) [See also 2.]
2. tsREhu He made it nine. (Esh-Sheybánee, and K voce waHRada.) [See also 1.]
tsRE liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained nine nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sabRaEa.)
4. AtsEwA They became nine: (S, K:) and they became ninety. (M and L in art. vlv.)

They were, or became, persons whose camels came to water [on the ninth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first; i. e.,] after an interval of nine days, [of which the first or last, or each of these, was not complete,] and eight nights. (S, * K, * TA.)
tasoEN: see tisoEapN.

tusoEN A ninth part; one of nine parts; (S, Msb, K,) as also tusuEN↓; (Msb;) and tasiyEN↓, (S, Msb, K,) agreeably with a rule which some hold to be applicable in the case of every similar fractional number; but Sh says, I have not heard tasiyEN on any authority but that of AZ. (TA.)
tisoEN fem. of tisoEapN, q. v.

Also A certain ZomC of the OaZomaMC of camels; (S, K, TA;) i. e., their coming to water [on the ninth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first; or, in other words,] after an interval of nine days, [of which the first or last, or each of these, is not complete,] and eight nights. (TA.)
Also The ninth young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.)

tusaEN The seventh and eighth and ninth nights of the [lunar] month; (K;) the three nights of the month which are after the nufal, because the last night of these is the ninth; (S;) among the nights of the month are three called gurarN, [pl. of gurRapN,] and after these are three called nufalN, and after these are three called tusaEN because the last of them is the ninth night: (Az, TA:) or the three nights of the commencement of the month, as some say; but the first of these explanations is more agreeable with analogy. (TA.)
tusuEN: see tusoEN.

tisoEapN, applied to denote a number, [namely Nine,] is masc.; and tisoEN↓, so applied, is fem.: (S:) the latter is also written tasoEN↓, with fet-h to the t; and is thus pronounced in the Kur xxxviii. 22, (Bd, MF,) accord. to one reading. (Bd.) You say tisoEapu rijaAlK [Nine men], and tisoEN nisowapK [Nine women]. (K.) When it means the things numbered, not the amount of the number, tsEp is imperf. decl., being regarded as a proper name: thus you say, tisoEapu Oakovaru mino vamaAniyapa [Nine things are more than eight things]. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xvii. 103], wa laqado MtayonaA muwsaI tisoEa MyaAtK bayRinaAtK [And we formerly gave unto Moses nine evident signs; generally understood to mean the principal miracles which he was empowered to perform, and which are differently enumerated in the K and other works; but by some supposed to mean statutes]. (K, * TA.)

In tisoEapa EaXara, which is masc., and tisoEa EaXorapa, which is fem., [each signifying Nineteen,] each of the two words ends with fet-h in every case, because they are two nouns which are regarded as one noun. (TA.) The former is pronounced by some of the Arabs tisoEapa EoXara: and the latter, thus in the dial. of El-Hijáz
[and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced tisoEa EaXirapa in the dial. of Nejd. (S in art. EXr.) In the Kur lxxiv. 30, some read, tisoEapa EoXara, making the E in EXr quiescent, instead of tisoEaha EaXara, from a dislike of this consecution of vowels in what is like one word. (Bd, TA. *)
[tisoEuwna, Ninety: and ninetieth.]

[tusaAEa, as meaning Nine and nine, or nine and nine together, or nine at a time and nine at a time, seems not to have been in use.] A'Obeyd says that more than OuHaAda and vunaMCa and vulaAva and rubaAEa has not been heard, except EuXaAra occurring in a verse of El-Kumeyt. (TA in art. EXr.)
tasiyEN: see tusoEN.

taAsiEN [Making to be nine with himself, or itself: and hence, ninth]. You say, huwa taAsiEu tisoEapK [He is the ninth of nine]: and taAsiEu vamaAniyapK [He is making eight to be nine with himself]: but it is not allowable to say, taAsiEN tisoEapF. (TA.)
[taAsiEa EaXara and taAsiEapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Nineteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv, q. v.]

taAsuwEaMCu, (Msb, TA, &c.,) or AltRaAsuwEaMCu, (S, K,) The tenth day of [the month] El-Moharram; (Msb, TA;) [the day] before the day of AlEaAXuwraMCu, (S,) or before the day of EaAXuwraMCu: (K:) or, accord. to some, the same as the day of AlEAXwrAC: (TA:) [see EAXwrAC, where this is explained:] it is a post-classical word: (Sgh, K:) J says, in the S, I think it post-classical: (Msb, TA:) but [SM says,] this requires consideration; for it was used by the Prophet: (TA:) one ought to say, that, with EAXwrAC, it has this form for the sake of resemblance; but as used alone, it must be conceded that it has not been heard [from the Arabs of the classical times]. (Msb.)
[mutasRaEN pass. part. n. of 2, q. v. See also muvalRavN.]
matosuwEN A rope consisting of nine strands. (TA.)

tiXoriynu [in Chaldee ???] A Greek name of each of two months, (K,) of the months of Autumn, called tiXoriynu AlOawRalu and tiXoriynu AlvRaAniI, [and both together tiXoriynaAni, the two Syrian months corresponding, respectively, to October and November O. S.,] before the two months whereof each is called kaAnuwnu. (TA.)

R. Q. 1. taEotaEa fiI AlkalaAmi, (Mgh, K,) inf. n. taEotaEapN, (S, Mgh,) He reiterated in speech, by reason of an impediment, or inability to say what he would; (S, Mgh, K;) as also tataEotaEa↓: (K:) and he was unable to say what he would, or to find words to express what he would say: (ElGhooree, Mgh:) taEotaEapN is the speech of him who is termed Oalovag. (TA.) And tEtE fiI AlquroMni He reiterated in reciting the Kur-án, and his tongue stuck fast in his doing so. (TA.)

taEotaEati AldRaAbRapu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) The beast stuck fast in the sand, (S, K,) or soft soil, (S,) or mire: (TA:) sometimes the verb is thus used. (S.) And tEtE said of a camel &c. signifies His feet sank into the soft soil, or soft sands. (TA.)

taEotaEahu He dragged him (namely another man) roughly, or vehemently, and agitated him: (S:) or he shook him, or shook him vehemently, (AA, K,) backwards and forwards, and treated him roughly: (AA:) he shook him roughly: (IDrd, K:) or he compelled him against his will, in an affair, so that he became disquieted, or agitated. (IF, K.)
tuEotiEa fulaAnN Such a one had his saying rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, as wrong, or erroneous. (TA.)
R. Q. 2. tataEotaEa: see R. Q. 1, first signification.
taEotaEN i. q. faOofaMCN or faOofaON [accord. to different MSS., as meaning One who reiterates his words much in speaking]. (AA, K.)

waqaEuwA fiI taEaAtiEa, [app. pl. of the inf. n. taEotaEapN,] They fell into convulsing perplexities, arising from evil and discordant and false rumours or the like, (fI OaraAjiyfa, q. v.,) and confusion. (AA, S, K.)
mutaEotaEN Afflicted by an injury which disquiets or agitates. (TA, from a trad.)

1. taEiba, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
taEaba
, (A, K,) inf. n. taEabN, (S, Msb,) He [a man and a beast] was, or became, fatigued, tired, wearied [by labour or journeying &c.], or jaded; (S, A, Msb;) contr. of AisotaraAHa. (K.) [taEabN, which, used as a simple subst., may be rendered Fatigue, tiredness, weariness, or the state of being jaded, is here said in the TA to be contr. of raAHapN; and to signify XidRapu AlEanaMCi, which may be rendered much fatigue &c.; but accord. to an explanation of the verb of EanaMCN in the S and TA in art. EnI, this word and taEabN signify the same. See also matoEabN.]

4. AtEb He fatigued, tired, wearied, or jaded, another; (S, Msb, K;) and himself, in a work that he imposed upon himself, or in which he laboured; and his travelling-camels, by urging them quickly, or by hard journeying. (TA.)

(tropical:) He broke a bone again after it had been set, or consolidated: or he caused a bone to have a defect in it, after it had been set, so that there remained in it a constant swelling, or resulted a lameness: AtEb AlEaZoma signifying OaEonatahu baEoda Aljabori: (so in the CK:) or OaEotabahu bEd Aljbr. (So in MS. copies of the K and in the TA. [In the latter, in art. Etb, this reading is confirmed; but a remark below, voce mutoEabN, rather favours the former reading, that of the CK.])
(tropical:) He filled a vessel; (A, K;) as, for instance, a drinking-cup, or bowl. (A.)
AtEb Alqawomu The people's cattle became fatigued, tired, wearied, or jaded. (K.)
taEibN Fatigued, tired, wearied, or jaded; as also mutoEabN↓; (S, Msb, K;) but not matoEuwbN. (S, K.) [taEobaAn↓, for taEobaAnN, fem. with p, is used in this sense in the present day.]
taEobaAn: see what next precedes.
matoEabN A place of taEab [or fatigue, &c.]:
and tropically, syn. with taEabN: pl. mataAEibu. (Har p. 431.)
mutoEabN: see taEibN.

Also (tropical:) A camel that has had a bone of one of his fore legs or hind legs broken and set, and has been fatigued beyond his power of endurance before the bone has consolidated, so that the fracture has become complete: whence the phrase EaZomN mutoEabN [app. meaning (tropical:) a bone broken again after its having been set, or consolidated: see 4]. (TA.)
A vessel, as, for instance, a drinking-cup, or bowl, (tropical:) filled. (TA.)
Water (tropical:) squeezed forth, or expressed, from the earth, to be drunk. (A, TA.)

matoEabapN [A cause of fatigue or weariness: a word of the same class as majobanapN and maboxalapN: loosely explained in Har p. 475 as meaning a place of fatigue]. One says, AisotixoraAju AlmuEamRaI matoEabapN liloxawaATiri [The eliciting of the meaning of that which is made enigmatical is a cause of fatigue to minds]. (A.)

1. taEasa, aor.
taEasa
, inf. n. taEosN; (S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) and taEsa, aor.
taEasa
; (Sh, AHeyth, A, IAth, K;) but the latter is not chaste; (A, TA;) or the former is used in addressing a person, saying taEasota; and the latter, in narration; (K;) accord. to Sh; but ISd says that this is strange; (TA;) He fell, having stumbled; contr. of AinotaEaXa: this is the primary signification: (S:) or he stumbled and fell (AHeyth, A, IAth, K) upon his hands and mouth, (AHeyth, TA,) or upon his face: (IAth, TA:) or he fell upon his face: (Er-Rustamee, Msb, TA:) [and this may also be meant by one of the explanations of the inf. n. in the TA, which is nukosN fiI safaAlK:] or he fell in any manner. (TA.) You say, by way of imprecation, taEasa waQnotakasa, meaning May he fall upon his face, and not rise after his fall until he fall a second time. (Msb.) And taEasa famaA QnotaEaXa waXiyka falaA QnotaqaXa [May he fall, having stumbled, or stumble and fall, &c., and not rise again; and may he be pricked with a thorn, and not extract the thorn]. (TA.) And accord. to certain of the Kilábees, taEasa signifies He missed his proof in litigation, and the object of his search in seeking. (TA.)
He perished. (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, S, K.) You say, taEasota, as though meaning Mayest thou perish. (ISh, TA.)
He became far removed. (A, K.)
He became lowered, or degraded. (A, K.) You say also, taEasa jadRuhu [His fortune, or good fortune, fell: or may his fortune, or good fortune, fall]. (K in art. Evr.)

taEasahu QllRehu, [aor.
taEasa
, inf. n. taEosN;] (A'Obeyd, A, Msb, K;) and AtEshu↓; (AHeyth, S, A, Msb, K;) the former unknown to Sb; (Az, TA;) God made him to fall, having stumbled: (S:) or to stumble and fall (AHeyth, A, K) upon his hands and mouth, (AHeyth, TA,) or upon his
face: (TA:) or to fall upon his face: (Msb:) or to fall in any manner. (TA.)
God destroyed him; or made him to perish. (A'Obeyd, S, K.)
God made him to become far removed. (A, K.)
God lowered, or degraded, him. (A, K.)

You say, by way of imprecation, taEosFA lahu May he [fall, having stumbled: or, stumble and fall: or, stumble and fall upon his hands and mouth: or, upon his face: or] fall upon his face: (Msb:) or may God make destruction to cleave to him: (S, TA:) [or may God destroy him.] Aboo-Is-hák says, in explanation of the phrase fataEosFA lahumo, in the Kur xlvii. 9, that it may be in the accus. case as meaning QllRehu OatoEasahumu↓. (TA.) A man also says, by way of imprecation, to his swift and excellent camel, when it stumbles, taEosFA, meaning May God throw thee down upon thy nostrils: expressing his disapproval of the stumbling of a beast of such age and strength: but if it be not a swift and excellent beast, and stumble, he says to it laEFA. (TA.) You say also, QllRehu OatoEasa↓ jadRahu [May God make his fortune, or good fortune, to sink!] (A.)
4: see taEasahu, in three places.
taEosN inf. n. of 1 [which see, throughout].
Also Evil; mischief. (K.)
taEisN: see what next follows.

taAEisN (A, K) and taEisN↓ (Msb, K) act. part. ns. of 1, [i. e., respectively, of taEasa and taEisa, accord. to rule, used intransitively,] (A, Msb, K,) both applied to a man: (K:) and the former, to fortune, or good fortune. (A.)

matoEasapN [A cause of falling after stumbling: or of stumbling and falling &c. (See 1.)] You say, hecaA AlOamoru manoHasapN matoEasapN [This affair is a cause of ill luck; a cause of falling &c.]. (A, TA.)

1. tafiva, aor.
tafava
, inf. n. tafavN, He left off, or abstained from, anointing himself, and shaving his pubes, and in consequence became dirty: (Msb:) or tafavN signifies the state of being dirty; (Mgh;) the state of having matted and dusty hair, or a dusty head, long left unanointed: (T, Mgh, K:) so in relation to the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage: (T, K:) thus explained by ISh; but not by any [other] of the lexicologists: he says that it is one of the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage; (T;) which is a conventional term of the professors, or lecturers, of the colleges: (Mgh:) accord. to I'Ab, it signifies the shaving, and shortening, or clipping, of the beard and mustache and [the hair of] the armpit, and slaughtering [of the victims], and casting [of the pebbles]: accord. to Fr, the slaughtering of the [victims termed] budon, and other victims, namely, kine, and sheep or goats, and shaving the head, and paring the nails, and the like: (T:) AO says that no poem is adduced as presenting an ex. of it: (Msb, TA:) and Zj says that it is not known by the lexicologists except from the expositors of the Kur-án; (T, M;) who say that it is the clipping the mustache, and paring the nails, and plucking out the hair of the armpit, and shaving the pubes, and clipping the hair [of the head]: (T:) or the plucking out the hair, and paring of the nails, and deviating from all that is prohibited to the muHorim: (M:) as though it were a passing from the state of UiHoraAm to the state of UiHolaAl: (T, M:) or, in the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage, the doing such things as paring the nails, and clipping the mustache, and shaving the pubes (S, K) and the head, and casting the pebbles, and slaughtering the budon, (S,) &c.: (S, K: [but in two copies of the S, this art. is omitted:]) or the doing away with the matted and dusty state of the hair, and pollution and dirt, absolutely. (TA.) Accord. to ISh, qaDaMCu AltRafavi means The doing away with the matted and dusty state of the hair by shaving, and paring the nails, and the like: (T:) or it means the doing away with the state of tafav, by clipping the mustache, and paring the nails, and plucking out the hair of the armpit, and shaving the pubes. (Mgh.) Accord. to IAar, vumRa liyaqoDuwA tafavahumo [in the Kur xxii. 30] means Then let them accomplish their needful acts of shaving and cleansing: (T:) or it means then let them do away with their dirtiness, by clipping the mustache, and paring the nails, and plucking out the hair of the armpit, and shaving the pubes, on the occasion of UiHolaAl: (Bd:) it is an allowance, after entering the state of UiHolaAl, of that which was forbidden them in the state of UiHoraAm. (Msb.)
fatafavati AldimaMCu makaAnahu occurs in a trad., meaning And the blood (lit. bloods) contaminated the place thereof. (TA.)

tafivN, (T, Mgh, K,) accord. to ISh, applied to a man, (T, Mgh,) Altered [in odour or the like], (mugayRarN, T,) or dusty, (mugobarRN, Mgh, K, or mutagibRirN, TA,) having matted and dusty hair, not having anointed himself, (T, Mgh, K, *) nor shaven his pubes. (T, Mgh. [In the former it is implied that this explanation is doubtful.])
4. AtfHhu [He gave him an apple]. You say, OatoHafaka mano OatofaHaka [He makes a present to thee who gives thee an apple]. (A: there immediately following the saying, fulaAnN tuHofatuhu tufRaAHapN.)
tafoHapN A sweet odour. (Abu-l-Khattáb, L.)

tufRaAHN, of the measure fuERaAlN; an Arabic word; [not arabicized;] (Msb;) [The apple, or apples;] a certain fruit, (L, Msb,) well known, (S, L, Msb, K,) plentiful in [the cooler parts of] the land of the Arabs: (AHn, TA:) the word is said by Abu-l-Khattáb to be derived from tafoHapN “ a sweet odour: ” (L:) the n. un. is with p: (S, L, Msb:) the pl. is tafaAfiyHu: (T:) and the dim. of the n. un. is tufayofyHapN↓. (L.) You say, fulaAnN tuHofatuhu tufRaAHapN [Such a one, his present is an apple]. (A.)
tufRaAHu AlHubRi and tufRaAHN cahabiIRN: see baAcanojaAnN.
tufRaAHu AlbarRi: see yaboruwHN, in art. brH.
AltRufRaAHapu also signifies (tropical:) The head of the thigh-bone, which is in the haunch-bone. (Kr, A, K.)
laTamona biAlEunRaAbi AltRufRaAHa [lit. They (women) slapped, with the jujubes, the apples] means, (tropical:) with the fingers, or the ends of the fingers, the cheeks. (A.)
tufayofiyHapN: see tufRaAHN.
matofaHapN A place where apples grow (L, K) in abundance. (L.)
tuforuwqN The qimaE [or base] of a date; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) a dial. var. of vuforuwqN [q. v.]: pl. tafaAriyqu. (TA.)

1. tafala, [in the CK, erroneously, tafila,] aor.
tafila
(S, M, Msb, K) and
tafula
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafolN, (T, S, M, Msb,) He spat; syn. baSaqa: (M, K:) [or rather, he spat, emitting a small quantity of saliva, generally in scattered portions, as when one spits forth some minute thing:] AltRafolu is similar to Albazoqu, but less in degree: (S, Msb: *) the first degree is Albazoqu; then, AltRafolu; then, AlnRafovu; and then, AlnRafoxu: (S:) AltRafolu with the mouth is [an action] never without somewhat of spittle: a blowing without spittle is [said to be] termed nafovN. (T.) Hence, tafolu AlrRaAqiI [The spitting of the charmer, in which he emits a small quantity of saliva at a time, in scattered portions: see also nafava]. (S.) One says also, caAqa maMCa AlbaHori fatafalahu, i. e. [He tasted the water of the sea, and] spirted it forth, by reason of dislike thereof. (TA.)

tafila, (M, K,) aor.
tafala
, (K,) inf. n. tafalN, (S, M, Mgh, K,) He, or it, (a thing, M,) became altered for the worse in odour, ill-smelling, or frouzy: (M, K:) he neglected, or left off the use of, perfume: (M:) he was unperfumed: (S:) he neglected, or left off the use of, perfume, and so became altered for the worse in odour, ill-smelling, or frouzy: (Mgh, TA:) and tafilato, aor. and inf. n. as above, she (a woman) stank, by reason of having neglected, or left off the use of, perfume and ointments: and also she perfumed herself: thus bearing two contr. significations. (Msb.)
4. Atflhu He, or it, made him, or it, to be altered for the worse in odour, ill-smelling, or frouzy, (K,) or unperfumed. (S.) The rájiz says,

[And she makes ambergris and musk, or the vesicle of musk, to have a bad odour, or to lose their fragrance]. (S.) And it is said of the sun, tutofilu AlrRiyHa [It makes the odour of the person to be bad]. (TA, from a trad.)
tafolN: see what next follows.

tufolN, (K,) or tafolN↓, (M, accord. to the TT,) and tufaAlN↓, (M, K,) vulgarly tifolN↓ and tifaAlN↓, (TA,) Spittle, or saliva, ejected from the mouth; syn. buSaAqN; (M, K;) as also tafalN↓: (Ibn-Abi-l- Hadeed, TA:) or it is similar to buSaAq. (TA.) [See 1.]
And Froth, or foam, (M, K,) of the sea; (TA;) and the like thereof. (M.)
tifolN: see tufolN.
maA OaSaAba fulaAnN mino fulaAnK UilRaA tifolFA TafiyfFA Such a one obtained not from such a one save a little. (T.)
tafalN: see tufolN.

tafilN, applied to a man; (S, M, K;) and tafilapN, applied to a woman, (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) as also mitofaAlN↓, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) which is a possessive epithet, (M,) or an intensive epithet, (Msb,) Altered for the worse in odour, ill-smelling, or frouzy: (M, K:) who has neglected, or left off the use of, perfume: (M:) unperfumed: (T, S:) who has neglected, or left off the use of, perfume, and so become altered for the worse in odour, illsmelling, or frouzy: (Mgh, TA:) stinking, (T, Msb,) by reason of having neglected, or left off the use of, perfume and ointments: (Msb:) the pl. of tafilapN is tafilaAtN; (T, Mgh, Msb;) applied to such women as are not to be prevented from going to the mosque, and in this case meaning unperfumed. (T, * Mgh, * TA.)
qawomN safilapN tafilapN [A company of men of the lowest and vilest sort]. (TA.)
tufaAlN and tifaAlN: see tufolN.
AlXRamosu mutofilapN [The sun makes the odour of the person to be bad]. (TA.)
mitofalapN A spittoon, or vessel in which to spit; syn. mibozaqapN. (TA.)
mitofaAlN: see tafilN.

1. tafiha, aor.
tafaha
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafahN, (JK, Msb, K, TA,) or tafohN, (Mgh, CK,) and tufuwhN (K) and tafaAhapN, (Msb, TA,) or this last is a mistake; (Mgh;) and tafaha, aor.
tafiha
, inf. n. tufuwhN; (JK;) It (a thing, JK, Mgh, Msb) was, or became, paltry, sorry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb;) and little, or small, in quantity or number. (JK, S, K.)

tafiha, aor.
tafaha
, inf. n. tufuwhN, He (a man) was, or became, stupid, or foolish. (JK, K.) And tafihato nafosuhu His mind became weak. (JK.)

tafaha, aor.
tafuha
; and tafiha, aor.
tafaha
; He, or it, was, or became, lean, or meagre; syn. gavRa. (K.) It is said in a trad. (S, K) of Ibn-Mes'ood, (K,) AlquroMnu laA yatofahu walaA yataXRaAnu, (S, K, [in the CK, erroneously, yutofahu and yutaXAnRu, and in some copies of the K, for the latter is put yntAn,]) i. e. laA yagivRu wa laA yaxolaqu (assumed tropical:) [The Kur-án will not become meagre, nor will it become worn out]: (K: [in the CK, erroneously, lA yugavRu w lA yuxolaqu:]) it is implied by the context in the S, that lA ytfh means will not become paltry, or mean: lAytXAnR means will not become worn out by reason of much repetition; from XanRu signifying “ a wornout water-skin. ” (TA.)
4. Atfh fiI EaTaAYihi [He was paltry, sorry, mean, or niggardly, in his gift;] he made his gift little, or small. (TA.)
tafihN: see taAfihN.

Also Insipid; tasteless; and so taAfihN↓. (KL.) You say OaToEimapN tafihapN Kinds of food having no taste of sweetness, or of sourness, or of bitterness; and some include bread and flesh-meat among these. (K.)

taAfihN (S, Mgh, Msb, KL, TA) and tafihN↓ (Mgh, KL, TA) applied to a thing, (JK, Mgh, Msb,) and the former to a man also, (TA,) Paltry, sorry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, KL, TA:) and little, or small, in quantity or number. (JK, S, TA, and KL in explanation of the former.)
taAfihu AlEaqoli A man having little sense, or intellect; (TA;) stupid, or foolish. (JK.)
See also tafihN.
taAfihN also signifies Afflicted, or distressed, by reason of disease and fatigue. (JK.)
mutafRahapN; (JK, TA;) so in the handwriting of Sgh; in the K, mutofahapN; (TA;) Easy, submissive, or tractable; applied to a she-camel. (JK, K.)
tiqodapN (JK, S, L, K) and taqodapN (Hr, L, K) and taqidapN (JK, L) Coriander-seed; syn. kuzobarapN. (IAar, JK, S, L, K.)
And Caraway-seed; syn. karawoyaMC. (IAar, Th, L, K.)
2. taqRanuwA OaroDahumo, (JK, K,) inf. n. tatoqiyna, (K,) They watered their land with thick, or muddy, water, [or water containing tiqon,] (JK, * K,) in order that it might become good. (K.)

4. Atqnhu, (K,) inf. n. UitoqaAnN, (JK, S,) i. q. OaHokamahu [He made it, or rendered it, (namely, a thing, JK, or an affair, S and K,) firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, sound, or free from defect or imperfection, by the exercise of skill; he made it firmly, strongly, solidly, compactly, so that it was firmly and closely joined or knit together, soundly, thoroughly, skilfully, judiciously, or well; he so constructed, constituted, established, settled, arranged, did, performed, or executed, it; he put it into a firm, solid, sound, or good, state, or on a firm, solid, sound, or good, footing]. (JK, S, K.) [And Atqn lahu signifies the same as Atqnhu: or he exercised, or possessed, the skill requisite for it; namely, an affair.] AlRaciy Oatoqana kulRa XRaIoCK, in the Kur xxvii. 90, means Who hath created everything firmly, strongly, solidly, &c., (OaHokama xaloqahu,) and made it, fashioned it, or disposed it, in the fit, proper, or right, manner. (Bd.) [You say also, Atqn Eilomahu, meaning He made his knowledge sound; or made himself thoroughly learned.] And Atqn Eanohu He knew it, or learned it, (namely, a tradition [&c.],) soundly, thoroughly, or well, from him. (TA in art. cbr.)

tiqonN The rusaAbap of water, (JK, Mgh, K,) in a rivulet or in the channel of a torrent, (K,) in the [season called] rabiyE; (Lth, JK, Mgh;) i. e., (Mgh,) [its sediment, or] the thick matter that is borne by it [and that sinks to the bottom; used for improving land]: (Lth, JK, Mgh:) and (K) the turonuwq of a well (Mgh, K) and of the channel of a torrent; i. e., the slime, mixed with black, or black and fetid, mud; accord. to the Jámi' of El-Ghooree. (Mgh.)

A thing by means of which one subsists, and makes good, or improves, the performance, or execution, or management, of an affair; as iron, and other things, of the jawaAhir [i. e. precious stones, or native ores,] of the earth: and anything by means of which a thing is made good, or improved, is called its tiqon. (TA.)
A skilful man: (JK, S, K:) pl. OatoqaAnN. (TA.)

[Hence, probably,] tiqonN [or Aibonu tiqonK] is also the name [or surname] of a certain man proverbial for his excellence in shooting. (S, K. [In the latter it is implied that this name or surname is AltRiqonu.]) The rájiz says,

L.foreign: yaramiI bihaA OaromaI mini Qboni tiqoni

sense.s: [One more skilled in shooting than Ibn-Tikn shoots it]. (S.)
Nature, or natural disposition. (JK, S, K.) You say, AlfaSaAHapu mino tiqonihi Chasteness of speech, or eloquence, is [a quality] of his nature. (S.)

dictScrap.label: Quasi tqI: or, accord. to some, tqw

sense.s:
1. taqaI, aor.
1a2i2a
(T, S, K, in art. wqI) and
1a2a2a
, (T, TA,) or taqiIa, aor.
1a2a2a
, (Msb, [but the correctness of this I greatly doubt, unless, as appears to be the case, it is meant to be understood as an intrans. verb,]) inf. n. taqoIN, (S and TA in art. tqI, [which art. I find in only one copy of the S,]) or tuqFI, (K,) or tuqaApN, (Msb, and also mentioned in the TA,) of which tuqFI is pl., or coll. n., (Kzz, IB, Msb,) and taqiyRapN (K) and tiqaMCN; (Lh, K;) and AitaqRaI↓, (T, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. AitRiqaMCN (Msb) and [quasi-inf. n.] taqiyRapN and tuqaApN; (S, art. wqI;) He feared God: (S and TA in art. tqI: all else that follows is from art. wqI except where reference is made to another art.:) or he was cautious of a thing; guarded, or was on his guard, against it; prepared, prepared himself, or was in a state of preparation, against it; or feared it: (K:) or he looked forward to a thing, and guarded against it, sought to avoid it, or was cautious of it. (T, TA.) [For other explanations of the latter verb, which apply also to the former, see art. wqI.] AitRaqaI↓ is originally AiwotaqaI; (T, S;) then AiytaqaI; then AitRaqaI; and when this came to be much in use, they imagined the t to be a radical part of the word, and made the word AitaqaI, aor. yataqiI, with fet-h to the t in each case, and without teshdeed; and not finding any analogue to it in their language, they said taqaI, aor. yatoqiI, like qaDaI, aor. yaqoDiI: (S:) or, as is said in the T, they suppressed the t, and the AitRaqaI changed into t, in AitRaqaI, and said taqaI, aor. yatoqiI. (TA.) A poet says, (namely, Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh, TA,)

or, as some read it, yataqiI, with the t movent, but without teshdeed; (S;) and this latter, accord.
to IB, is the right reading. (TA.) [See this verse explained in art. Avr.] IB adds that Aboo-Sa'eed [app. meaning As] disallowed taqaI, aor. yatoqiI, inf. n. taqoIN; saying that it would require the imperative to be Aitoqi, which is not said; and this, he states, is right: [for] J says that the imperative used is taqi [Fear thou, or beware thou, &c.], as in taqi QllRehi [Fear thou God]; and to a woman, taqiI; formed from the verb AitaqaI, without tesh-deed, by the suppression of the A. (TA.)
