4. maA AatoqaAhu lilRehi (S, TA) How great is his reverential, or pious, fear of God! (TA.)
mA AtqAhu is also said of a saddle, as meaning How good is it for not galling the back! (TA.)
8: see 1, in two places; and see also art. wqI.
tuqFI: see taqowaI.
tuqaApN: see taqowaI, in two places.

In the phrase in the Kur [iii. 27], UilRaA Oano tatRaquwA minohumo tuqaApF, it may be an inf. n. [so that the meaning may be Unless ye fear from them with a great fearing (see 1)]: or it may be a pl. [app. of taqiIRN, like as kumaApN is pl. of kamiIRN, so that the meaning may be unless ye fear from them, being fearful]: but it is better to regard it as an inf. n. because another reading is taqiyRapF. (M, TA.)

taqiIRN, applied to a man, (Msb, K, TA,) i. q. waqiIRN (TA) and mutRaqK (S) [Fearing; cautious; &c.: (see 1:) and particularly having a reverential, or pious, fear of God: or simply pious: or one who preserves, or guards, himself, accord. to some, exceedingly, or extraordinarily, from sin, either of commission or of omission: (see 8 in art. wqI:)] accord. to IDrd, one who preserves, or guards, himself from punishment [in the world to come], and from acts of disobedience, by righteous conduct: from waqayotu nafosiI: said by the grammarians to be originally waquwIN; then, taquwIN: or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr, [originally] of the measure faEiylN, as is indicated by the first of its pls. mentioned below: but he who says that it is [originally] of the measure faEuwlN says that it has that pl. because it has become like a word [originally] of the measure faEiylN: (TA:) or righteous, virtuous, just, or honest; (Msb in art. tqI;) contr. of faAjirN: (idem in art. br:) pl. OatoqiyaMCu (Msb in art. tqI, and K) and tuqawaMCu, (K,) which is extr., and of a class disallowed by Sb, (TA,) [and app. also tuqaApN, q. v. suprà.]
taqiyRapN: see what next follows.

taqowaI, or taqowFI, accord. to different readings in the Kur ix. 110, (Bd,) [of which readings the former is the more common,] is originally taqoyaA, (K,) [or taqoyFA,] or [rather waqoyaA, or waqoyFA, and then] waqowaI, of the measure faEolaI, from waqayotu, (ISd, TA,) or, accord. to MF, the right opinion is that it is [waqowFI,] of the measure faEowalN, (TA,) and is thus transformed in order to make a distinction between the subst. and the epithet such as xazoyaA and SadoyaA: (K:) it is a subst. from AitRaqaI or waqaI; (Msb, K;) [and signifies Fear; caution; &c.: (see 1:) and particularly reverential, or pious, fear of God: or simply piety: or the preservation, or guarding, of oneself, accord. to some, exceedingly, or extraordinarily, from sin, either of commission or of omission: or the preservation, or guarding, of oneself from punishment in the world to come, and from acts of disobedience, by righteous conduct: or righteousness, virtue, justice, or honesty: (see taqiIRN:) its explanations in relation to religion are many and various, but are all resolvable into fear of God, or of sin; or the preservation, or guarding, of oneself from sin:] and taqiyRapN↓ and tuqaApN↓ are syn. with each other (S) and with taqoway, (Msb,) and are used as inf. ns. of AitRaqaI: (S:) and tuqFI↓ [also] is syn. with taqoway; (S;) or it is pl. of tuqaApN↓, or a coll. n., (Kzz, IB, Msb,) like as TulFI is of TulaApN, (Kzz, IB,) and as ruTabN is of ruTabapN. (Msb.) waMtaAhumo taqowaAhumo, in the Kur xlvii. 19, means And hath explained to them, (Bd,) or suggested to them, (Jel, TA,) what they should fear, or that from which they should preserve themselves: (Bd, Jel, TA:) or hath aided them to practise their taqowaI: (Bd:) or hath given them the recompense of their tqwI. (Bd, TA.) And huwa Oaholu AltRaqowaI, in the Kur lxxiv. last verse, means He is entitled, or worthy, to be feared; or to be reverentially, or piously, feared. (Bd, Jel, K.)
huwa OatoqaI mino fulaAnK [He is more fearing, or cautious, &c., than such a one; more reverentially, or piously, fearful of God; or more pious; &c.;] he has more taqowaI than such a one. (TA.)

10. AsttkR AltRikRapa, (IDrd, K,) or biAltRikRapi, (Msb,) He inserted the tikRap in [the double upper border of] the drawers, or trousers. (IDrd, Msb, K.) You say also, huwa yasotatiku biAlHariyri He makes use of a tikRap of silk. (A.)

tikRapN The band [that is inserted in the double upper border] of the drawers, or trousers; (IDrd, K;) [generally, a strip of cotton, which is often embroidered at each end; sometimes, of net-work; and] sometimes, of silk: (A:) IDrd thinks it to be an adventitious word, though used in ancient times; (TA;) and IAmb says, I think it to be arabicized: (Msb:) pl. tikakN. (S, Msb, K.)

mitakRu The thing by means of which the tikRap is inserted in [the double upper border of] the drawers, or trousers. (TA.) [It is generally a slender piece of wood, having at one end a loop through which a portion of the tkRp is passed.]
takiYa &c.: see art. wkO.

1. takila Ealayohi, aor.
1a2a2a
, a dial. var. of AitRakala. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K) See art. wkl; where, also, see tukalapN, &c.

1. talRahu, (T, S, * M, Msb, K,) aor.
talula
, inf. n. talRN, (M, Msb,) He prostrated him, or threw him down; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) [as some say,] upon the talR: (TA:) or he threw him down (M, K, TA) upon his taliyl, i. e., (TA,) upon his neck, and his cheek: (M, K TA:) but the former is the more approved; and thus it is explained as used in the phrase watalRahu lilojabiyni [in the Kur xxxvii. 103], (M,) and he prostrated him, or threw him down, (Aboo-Is-hák, T, S, Bd,) upon his side, so that the side of his forehead fell upon the ground; (Bd;) or upon his mouth; (Katá- deh, T;) or upon his face. (Bd.) And talRa AlnRaAqapa He made the she-camel to lie down upon her breast. (TA.)
He threw it upon the ground: said of any corporeal thing. (M.)

talRa, aor.
talula
(IAar, T, K) and
talila
, (K,) [the latter anomalous in this case, and doubtful,] also signifies He poured (IAar, T, K, TA) into the hand of another. (TA.) And talRa AlXRaIoCa fiI yadihi He gave, or delivered, the thing to him: (M, K *:) or he threw, or put, the thing into his hand. (K.) The Prophet says, bayonaA OanaA naAYimN Outiytu bimafaAtiyHi xazaAYini AlOaroDi fatulRato fiI yadiI, i. e. [While I was sleeping, I had the keys of the treasures of the earth brought to me,] and they were poured into my hand: (IAar, T, M:) or were thrown, or put, into my hand. (IAmb, M.)
Also, (K,) inf. n. talRN, (M,) He lowered, or let down, the rope into the well, (M, K,) with the hand, on the occasion of drawing water. (M.)

sawoCK talRahu bitilRapi↓, [aor.
talula
, accord. to rule,] He charged him, or upbraided him, with an evil, or a foul, thing. (Th, M, K.)

talRa, aor.
talila
(IAar, T, M, K) and
talula
, (K,) [the latter anomalous in this case, and doubtful,] He was, or became, prostrated, or thrown down; (M, K) he fell, or fell down. (IAar, T, M, K.)

talRa jabiynuhu, (M, K,) aor.
talila
(T, M, K) and
talula
, (K,) [the latter anomalous in this case also, and doubtful,] inf. n. talRN, (T, M,) The side of his forehead sweated, or exuded sweat. (M, K.) And in like manner the verb is used in relation to a wateringtrough. (Lh, M.)
talilot is an imitative sequent to Dalilot. (M.)
4. AtlR AlmaAYiEa He made the fluid, or liquid, to drop, or fall in drops. (K.)

R. Q. 1. talotalahu, (S,) inf. n. talotalapN, (M, K,) He moved him, agitated him, shook him, put him into a state of motion or commotion; (S, M, K;) or did so vehemently: (S, K, and Mgh in art. tr:) he shook him, or shook him violently, (namely, a drinker,) and ordered him to breathe in his face, that he might know whether he had drunk [wine or the like], or not; (TA in this art. and art. tr;) as also tarotarahu, and mazomazahu. (TA in the latter art.)
talotalapN also signifies Hard journeying: and rough, or severe, or vehement, driving. (K.) You say, talotala AlrRajulu The man was rough, or severe, or vehement, in his driving. (M.)

talotalapu bahoraMCa is [The tribe of] Bahrà's pronouncing the t of
tafoEaluwna with kesr; (M, K;) saying tifoEaluwna, and tiXohaduwna, and the like. (M.)

talRN, accord. to Lth, [and accord. to general present usage,] A mound, or hill, of dust, or earth, [or rubbish,] pressed together, not natural: but this is a mistake [if meant as an explanation of the proper application], for with the Arabs it signifies a natural hill: En-Nadr says that it is of the smaller sort of UikaAm [pl. of OakamapN]; it is of the height of a house, or tent, and the breadth of its back is about ten cubits; it is smaller than the Oakamap, has fewer stones, gives growth to nothing good, and its stones are compacted together exactly like those of the Oakamap: (T:) [the mound, or artificial hill, above mentioned, is what is meant by its being said,] the talR of dust, or earth, is well known: and the word signifies also a heap of sand: (M, K:*) in both of these senses from AltRalRu signifying “ the throwing upon the ground ” anything of a corporeal kind: (M:) also a hill (M, K, TA) overtopping what is adjacent to it: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OatolaAlN (M, TA) and OatulRN (TA) and [of mult.] tilaAlN (T, S, Msb, K) and tuluwlN. (TA.)
Also A pillow: pl. OatolaAlN, which is extr.: or the pl. signifies certain sorts of cloths, or of garments: (K, TA:) or, as some say, of pillows. (TA.)
talRapN [inf. n. un. of 1, by Golius erroneously written tulRapN, and wrongly explained by him,] A single act of pouring [&c.]. (T, K.)
A single act of lying upon the side. (K.)
See also talotalapN.
tilRapN A mode, or manner, of lying upon the side. (Fr, K.)
Sluggishness, laziness, or indolence. (Fr, T, K.)

A state, or condition. (S, M, K) You say, huwa bitilRapi sawoCK He is in an evil state or condition; like as you say bibiyoYapi swC: (S:) and baAta bitilRapi sawoCK He passed the night in an evil state or condition. (M.)
A thing; as in the saying, talRahu bitilRapi sawoCK [explained above]: see 1. (Th, M, K.)

I. q. bilRapN, (T, M,) or balalN, as also talalN↓: (K:) Abu-s-Semeyda' says that tilRapN and bilRapN and talalN and talRapN are all one [i. e. Moisture]. (T.) One says, [app. to a person suspected of having drunk wine or the like,] maA hecihi AltRilRapu bifiyka i. e. AlbalRapu [What is this moisture in thy mouth?]. (T, M.)
talalN: see tilRapN.
AltRalaAl in the phrase huwa AlDRalaAlu bonu AltRalaAli is an imitative sequent. (S, K.)

taliylN Prostrated, or thrown down; as also matoluwlN↓: (IAar, T, M, K:) [pl. of the former talRaI, like as SaroEaI is pl. of SariyEN, and qatolaI of qatiylN, &c.; as in the phrase] qawomN talRaI A company of men prostrated, or thrown down. (M, K.)

The neck: (T, M, K:) and the cheek: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OatilRapN and [of mult.] tululN and talaAYilu. (M, K.) You say, lahu taliylN kajicoEi AlsRaHuwqi [He has a neck like the trunk of the tall palm-tree]. (TA.)
AltRalaAlapu is an imitative sequent to AlDRalaAlapu. (T, * S, M, * K.)
talotalapN inf. n. of R. Q. 1 [q. v.].
Also Hardship, difficulty, distress, or adversity: (M, K:) pl. talaAtilu, (TA,) signifying hardships, difficulties, &c. (Aboo-Turáb, T, S, M.)

A drinking-vessel that is made of the envelope (qiyqaMCap, S, or qiyqaMC, M and K) of the spadix of a palm-tree; (S, M, K;) so called because what it contains is poured into the throat; (T;) as also talRapN↓: (M, K:) it is said that nabiyc is drunk with it. (TA.)
talRN is an imitative sequent to DaAlRN. (T, * S, M, * K.)
matalRN A place of prostrating. (TA.)

matalRN [as a subst.] A thing with which one prostrates: (M, K:) and hence a spear: (Msb:) and [as an epithet], applied to a spear, with which one prostrates: (T, * S, M:) or, applied to a spear, erect; or even and erect. (K.)
Strong; (S, M, K;) applied to a man and to a camel (M, K, TA) &c. (TA.)
A man erect in prayer: (T, M, K:) so accord. to Lth, who cites the saying,
but this is a mistake; for yutilRuwna is from talRaI, and means, who make prayer to follow prayer. (T.)
mutalRilN One who prostrates much, or often; who does so by twisting his leg with the leg of another. (T.)
matoluwlN: see taliylN.
Q. 4. AitolaOabRa: &c.: see art. tlb.
talaAna i. q. QloMna [At the present time; now]: (As, K:) the t is added, as in taHiyna. (A'Obeyd &c.) See art. Ayn.

Q. Q. 4. AitolaOabRa, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. AitoliYobaAbN, (S, K,) It (a thing, M, or an affair, or a case, S, K, or a road, A) was, or became, uniform or undeviating, (A,) right, or rightly directed or ordered: (S, M, A, K:) or (M) it (a thing, M, or a road, S, K) was, or became, extended, (Fr, T, S, M, A, K,) and right, direct, even, or uniform: (S, M, K: *) or (M) it (a thing, M) was, or became, set up, or erect. (M, A, K.) You say, marRuwA faQnolaOabRa bihimu AlTRariyqu [They went along, and the road was, or became, uniform, &c., with them; i. e., their road was, or became, uniform, &c.]. (A.) And AtlObR Oamoruhumo [Their affair, or case, was, or became, right, or rightly directed or ordered]. (A.)
He (an ass) raised his breast and head. (S, K.)
This verb and its derivatives are mentioned in the [T and] S and K in the present art.; but they are held by [ISd and] IB to be radically quadriliteral. (TA.)
talobN Loss; or the state of being lost; or perdition. (A, K.) One says, tabRFA lahu talobFA, (Lth, T,) or tabRFA lahu watalobFA [which may be rendered May God decree loss and perdition to him]. (K.)
tulaOobiybapN a subst. (S, M, K) from AitolaOabRa; (Fr, T, S, M, K;) [signifying The state of being uniform or undeviating, right, &c.;] like TumaOoniynapN [from AiTomaOanRa]. (TA.)

tawolabN, perfectly decl. [when used as a proper name as well as when used as an appellative], because it is of the measure fawoEalN; (Sb, S;) for we judge its t to be a radical, and its w to be augmentative, because fawoEal is more common [as the measure of a noun] than tafoEal; (M;) but accord. to Suh, the t is a substitute for w, and, if so, it should be mentioned in art. wlb; (TA;) A young ass; syn. jaHoXN: (S, K:) or the foal of a wild ass, when he has completed a year. (M.) And OumRu tawolab is an appellation given to The she-ass. (S.)
The former is sometimes metaphorically applied to (tropical:) A [young] man: (M:) or a boy. (S.)

mutolaYibRN [Uniform or undeviating,] right, or rightly directed or ordered [&c.: see the verb]; as also musolaHibRN. (Asudot;, T) Also applied to a rule, (A, TA,) as meaning Uniform, undeviating, or of general application; uniformly, or constantly, obtaining. (TA.)
mataAlibu [app. pl. of matolabN or matolibN] The places where a wound causes death; syn. maqaAtilu. (IAar, T.)
Oatolaja: and tawolajN: see art. wlj.

1. talada, aor.
talida
(T, S, M, Msb, K;) and
taluda
, (T, sudot;, M, K,) inf. n. tuluwdN; (S, M, Msb, K;) [and AitRalada↓; (see Ham p. 699;)] It (property, consisting of camels or the like, syn. maAlN, T, S, M, &c.) was, or became, old, or long-possessed; (Msb;) such as is termed tilaAd. (T, S, M, Msb, K.)
talada fulaAnN EinodanaA Such a one was born of parents at our abode, or home. (L.)

And talada, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
taluda
, (M, K,) inf. n. as above; (T, L;) and talida, aor.
talada
; (K;) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (As, T, S, M, K,) fiI baniI fulaAnK among the sons of such a one, (S,) and bayonahumo among them, (M,) and bimakaAnK in a place. (As, T, L.)
See also 2.

2. tlRd, (IAar, T, K,) inf. n. tatoliydN; (K;) or talada↓; (so in the L as on the authority of IAar, and accord. to Lh as is said in the TA;) i. q. jamaEa and manaEa [app. as meaning He collected and defended property]; (IAar, T, L, K;) said of a man. (IAar, T, L.)

4. Atld, (T, S, L.) and Atld maAlFA, (T, M, Msb, K,) He got, obtained, or acquired, (AitRaxaca,) property [such as is termed tilaAd, as is implied in the T and M and K]: (T, S, L, Msb:) or he possessed
property such as is termed tilaAd. (So accord. to the explanation of the act. part. n., q. v., in the Mgh.)
8: see 1.
talodN: see tilaAdN, in two places.
tulodN: see tilaAdN, in two places.
Also The young one of an eagle. (M, K.)
taladN: see tilaAdN:
and taliydN.

tilaAdN, applied to maAl [i. e. property, consisting of camels or the like], (T, S, M, &c.,) Old, or long-possessed; as also taAlidN↓ and taliydN↓, (Mgh, Msb,) both of these meaning old, original, property, (A,) and mutoladN↓: (L:) or original, old, or long-possessed, born at one's own abode, or home; as also taAlidN↓ and UitolaAdN↓: (S:) contr. of TaArifN (S, A, Mgh, Msb) and TariyfN: (Mgh, Msb:) or born at the owner's abode, or house; or that brings forth there; (M, K;) as also taAlidN↓ (K) and talodN↓ and tulodN↓, (M, K,) and taladN↓ (K) and tilydN↓ and UitolaAdN↓, (M, K,) like UisonaAmN, (M, [in the CK written AatolOad, and so accord. to the MS,]) and mutoladN↓;]) (M, K; [written in a copy of the M mutalRd;]) wherefore, [i. e. because of the meaning,] Yaakoob judges that the t is a substitute for w; [as is said to be the case in the S;] but this is not a valid decision; for, were it so, the word in some of its variations would be reduced to its original: (M:) or any old, or long-possessed, property, (T, M, L,) consisting of animals &c., (M, L,) inherited from parents; (T, M, L;) as also taAlidN↓ (T, L) and taliydN↓ and mutoladN↓ (T, M, L [the last written in a copy of the T mNtolidN, and in a copy of the M mutalRd,]) and talodN↓ and tulodN↓ and UitolaAdN↓, as above: (M:) or slaves, or pasturing beasts, that breed at one's own abode, or home, and become old, or long possessed: (ISh, as related by Sh:) or that which you yourself breed, or rear. (As, T.) [See also taliydN, below.

Hence,] hunRa mino tilaAdiI, said by a man, (namely, Ibn-Mes'ood, M,) in reference to certain chapters (suwar) of the Kur-án, meaning (tropical:) They are of those which I acquired (or learned, L) long ago from the Kur-án: (S, M, L:) thus saying, he likened them to the property, or camels &c., called tilaAdN. (M, L.)
[Az says,] I heard a man of Mekkeh say, tilaAdiIbimakRapa, i. e. miylaAdiI [app. meaning My birth was in Mekkeh]. (T.)
taliydN: see tilaAdN, in three places.

Also That which is born at the abode, or home, of another than thyself, and which, while young, thou afterwards purchasest, and which remains with thee: (As, T.) or one who is born in a foreign country, and is carried away while young to the territory of the Arabs: (Mgh:) or one who is born in a foreign country, and then brought away while young, and who grows up in the territory of the Muslims; (S, K;) as also taladN↓: (K:) or i. q. muwalRadN and muwalRadapN, [masc. and fem.,] meaning one that is born at thine own abode, or home: (ISh, T: [see also tilaAdN:]) or one who has parents at thine own abode, or home; whereas muwalRadN signifies one who has only one parent there: (Mgh, from the Tekmileh [of the 'Eyn]:) the fem. is with p; (S;) signifying a female slave who is born in a foreign country, and is carried away, and grows up in the territory of the Arabs: (Kt, T:) or a female slave whose father and family and all her relations are in one country and who is herself in another: (ISh, L in art. wld:) or a female slave born the property of a people with whom are her parents: (L in art. wld:) or a female slave inherited by her owner; if born at his own abode, or home, [of a mother already belonging to him,] she is called waliydapN: (T, L:) you say rajulN taliydN; pl. tuladaMCu: and AimoraOapN taliydN [and taliydapN]; pl. talaAYidu (Lh, M, L) and tuludN. (Lh, L.) It is related in a trad. of Shureyh, that a man purchased a female slave, and the two parties made it a condition that she should be a muwalRadap; but the purchaser found her to be a taliydap, and therefore returned her: (S, Mgh:) a muwalRadap is like a tilaAd, i. e. born at thine own abode, or home; (S;) or born in the territory of the Muslims. (Mgh.)
Also, metaphorically, (tropical:) A child, absolutely. (Har p. 317.)
taAlidN: see tilaAdN, in four places.
taAlidN baAlidN: see art. bld.
UitolaAdN, by some written OatolaAdN: see tilaAdN, in three places.
mutoladN, applied to maAl, (S, Msb,) pass. part. n. of 4: (Msb:) see tilaAdN, in three places.

[Hence,] xuluqN mutoladN, (M, L, TA,) in the K, mutalRadN, said to be like muEaZRamN, but this is a mistake, (TA,) [and in the CK, xaloqN is erroneously put for xuluqN,] (assumed tropical:) An old, or a long-possessed, natural disposition, or quality. (M, L, K.) IAar cites as an ex. this verse:

L.foreign: maA caA ruziynaA minoki OamRa maEobadi
mino saEapi AlHilomi wa xuloqK mutolad

sense.s: [app. meaning What has been experienced from us, on thy part, Umm-Maabad, of largeness of forbearance, and of long-possessed good natural dispositions, or qualities? ruziynaA seems to be here used for ruziYonaA; or the latter may be the correct reading]. (M, L.)
mutolidN [act. part. n. of 4:] A possessor of property such as is termed tilaAd: and hence,
A first owner or proprietor; as the weaver of a piece of cloth, and the man who delivers his she-camel [and is owner of her young one]. (Mgh.)

taloEapN High, or elevated, land or ground: (AO, S, K:) and low, or depressed, land or ground: (AO, S, Msb, K:) thus bearing two contr. significations, (S, K,) accord. to AO: (S:) or it has not these significations, but means a water-course from the upper part of a valley to its lower part; therefore sometimes its upper part is described [by this name], and sometimes its lower part; (IAar, IB, TA:) or it has the second of the significations above, (Msb, K,) and the first, (K,) and signifies also a water-course (Msb, K) from the upper part of a valley: (Msb:) and also, (K,) or, accord. to IDrd, (TA,) the wide part of the mouth of a valley: and a high, or an elevated, piece of land or ground: (IDrd, K:) sometimes, says IDrd, it has this last application; but the former is the original signification: (TA:) it is also said to signify high, or elevated, and rugged, land or ground, in which the torrent goes to and fro, and from which it then pours to another tlEp, lower than it; and which is fertile in plants, or herbage: (L, TA:) or a water-course from the higher part of the ground to the bottom of a valley: (AA, S:) pl. tilaAEN (AA, S, Msb, K) and talaEaAtN: (K:) and, (K,) or, accord. to Sh, (TA,) tilaAEN signifies water-course flowing from acclivities and the [eminences termed] nijaAf and the mountains, until they pour into the valley: (Sh, K:) to which Sh adds, the tlEp of the mountain being formed by the water's coming and furrowing and excavating it until it escapes from it: (TA:) but tlAE are nowhere except [the word UilRAa has been dropped in the CK] in the SaHaAraI [or deserts]; (Sh, K;) and sometimes a tlEp comes from a distance of five leagues (faraAsix) to the valley; and when it flows from the mountains, and falls into the SHArI [or deserts], it excavates in them what resembles a moat: when it becomes so large as to be like the half, or two thirds, of the valley, it is termed mayovaMCu: (Sh, TA:) taloEapN is also said to be like rHbp [i. e. raHabapN or raHobapN, app. as meaning the part of a valley in which its water flows into it from its two sides]; and the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is said to be taloEN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., fayajiIoCu maTarN laA yamotaniEu minohu canabu taloEapK [And a rain will come, in consequence of which the end of a water-course will not be impeded]: meaning to denote its abundance, and that no place will be exempt from it. (TA.) And in a prov., fulaAnN laA yamonaEu canaba taloEapK [Such a one will not impede the end of a water-course]: (K, * TA:) applied to the abject and contemptible. (K.) And in another, (ISh,) laA Oaviqu bisayoli taloEatka [I do not, or will not, trust in the flow of thy water-course]: applied to him in whom one does not trust: (ISh, K:) i. e. I do not, or will not, trust in what thou sayest, and what thou adducest: characterizing the person as a liar. (ISh.) And in another, (IAar,) maA OaxaAfu UilRaA mino sayoli taloEatiI [I fear not save from the flow of my water-course]: i. e., from the sons of my uncle, and my relations: (IAar, K:) for he who descends the water-course is in danger: if the torrent come, it sweeps him away. (IAar.)

1. talifa, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
talafa
, (K,) inf. n. talafN, (Lth, T, S, M, &c.,) He, or it, (a thing, Lth, T, S, Msb, of any kind, Lth, T,) perished, passed away, was not, was no more, became nonexistent or annihilated; or went away, no one knew whither; or became in a bad, or corrupt, state; became corrupted, vitiated, marred, or spoiled; [in this sense the verb is often used in the present
day;] or he died: syn. halaka; (M, K;) and of the inf. n., EaTabN (Lth, T,) and halaAkN. (Lth, T, S.) [See also talafN, below.]

4. Atlfhu He caused him, or it, (a thing, S, Msb, or property, M,) to perish, pass away, or be no ore; or to go away, no one knew whither; or to become corrupted, vitiated, marred, or spoiled: (S, M:) or he made it (his property, T) to pass away, come to an end, come to nought, or be exhausted; destroyed, wasted, consumed, or exhausted, it; (T, K;) by prodigality. (T.) [See an ex. in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil cited voce Oaxolafa.]
El-Farezdak says,
(so in the T and L,) or

(so in some copies of the K,) or qado balagonaA qiraAhumu, (so in other copies of the K and in the TA,) or qd faEalonaA qrAhm, (so in the O,) i. e., [accord. to the different readings, How many a generous company of men has there been, or how many guests of the night have there been, to whom we have brought their entertainment, and] we have found the fates to be destructive, (T, K, *) and they have found them to be so: (T:) it is like the phrase OatayonaA fulaAnFA faOaboxalonaAhu and OajobanRaAhu: (TA:) or we found the fates to destroy us, and they found them to destroy them: or we made the fates to be destruction to them, and they made them to be destruction to us: (ISk, K:) he means, we engaged with them in vehement fight, and slew them. (TA.)

talafN A perishing, passing away, &c. [See 1.] (Lth, T, S, &c.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) UinRa mina Alqarafi AltRalafu (T, TA) Verily, from the being near to pestilence, or epidemic disease, there results death, or perdition. (T.) And in a prov., AlsRalafu talafN [The paying for a thing beforehand is a cause of perishing to one's property]. (TA.) And one says, cahabato nafosuhu talafFA and TalafFA, (S, K,) both meaning the same, (S,) His blood went for nothing, or as a thing of no account, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct. (S, K.)
talifN, (M,) or taAlifN↓, (Msb, TA,) part. n. of 1, Perishing, &c.; (M, Msb, * TA;) as also talofaAnN↓, which is post-classical. (TA.)
talofapN A [hill, mountain, or mass of rock, such as is termed] haDobap, difficult of access, so that he who attempts it fears perdition, or death. (ElHejeree, M.)
talofaAnN: see talifN.
taAlfN: see talifN.

matolafN A place of perishing or perdition: (K:) a [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap; (S, K;) because most of those who traverse it perish; and so matolafapN↓; (TA;) or the latter signifies a [desert such as is termed] qafor: (M:) the pl. of the former [or of both] is mataAlifu. (TA.)

rajulN mutolifN limaAlihi, (Msb,) or rajulN mitolafN↓, and mitolaAfN↓, (M,) A man who destroys, or wastes, his property: (M:) or the last has an intensive signification, (Msb,) meaning who destroys, or wastes, his property much. (S.) You say also, rajulN muxolifN mutolifN, (K, and Har p. 312,) or mixolafN mitolafN↓, (TA in art. xlf,) and mixolaAfN, mitolaAfN↓, (K, and Har ubi suprà,) meaning A man of courage and liberality, who makes what he takes as spoil, of the property of his enemies, to supply the place of that which he consumes by expenditure to satisfy the claims of his friends. (Har ubi suprà.)
mitolafN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
matolafapN: see matolafN.
Also A deep hollow, cavity, or pit, where one looks down upon destruction. (M.)
mitolaAfN: see mutolifN, in two places.
matoluwfN [i. q. munokarN, q. v.; i. e.] contr. of maEoruwfN: but this is post-classical. (TA.)
tiloka and taloka and taAlika: see art. tA.
Q. 1. talomaca He was, or became, a tilomiyc [or disciple, &c.], lifulaAnK to such a one. (TA, passim.)

tilomiycN A disciple; a pupil; a learner: or a special servant of a teacher: so says 'Abd-El- Kádir El-Baghdádee, who composed a treatise solely on this word: (MF, TA:) or simply a servant; a follower; a dependant: pl. talaAmiycu (L, TA) [and talaAmicapN].

1. talaA He followed; or went, or walked, behind, or after. (IAar, T.) You say, talawotuhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
taluwa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tuluwRN (S, M, Msb, K) and talowN, (Er-Rághib, MF,) I followed him or it; or went, or walked, behind, or after, him or it; (S, M, Msb, K;) namely, a man [&c.]; (S, Msb;) immediately, or without intervention; and sometimes it means bodily [or in reality]; and sometimes, virtually, or in effect: (Er-Rághib:) and so talayotuhu; (K;) and talRayotuhu↓, (As, * T, * K,) inf. n. tatoliyapN. (K.) The phrase, in the Kur xci. 2, waAlqamari UicaA talaAhaA means By the moon when its rising follows the rising thereof; i. e., the rising of the sun; at the beginning of the lunar month: (Bd:) or, when it follows in rising the setting thereof, (Bd, Jel,) on the night of the full moon: (Bd:) or, when it follows it in becoming round, and in fullness of light; (M, * Bd;) i. e., when it follows it in the way of imitation, and in respect of rank; for the moon borrows its light of the sun, and is to it in the place of a successor. (Er-Rághib.) Here, Ks pronounced tlAhA with imáleh, [either because talayotu is a dial. var. of talawotu, or] because, although it has w for its last radical letter, it occurs with words that may be so pronounced, namely, yagoXaAhaA and banaAhaA. (M.)
talawotu AlOibila (tropical:) I drove, or brought, or gathered, the camels together, from their several quarters: because the driver follows the driven. (A, TA.)
huwa yatoluw fulaAnFA He imitates such a one, and follows what he does; he follows him in action. (T.)

talaA, (T,) first pers. talawotu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
taluwa
, (T,) inf. n. tilaAwapN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) He read, or perused, or he recited, (T, M, K,) the Kur-án, (S, M, Msb, K,) or any discourse, or piece of language: (M, K:) or he followed it, (I'Ab, T, S, * M,) and did according to it; (I'Ab, Mujáhid, T;) namely, the Scripture: (I'Ab, Mujáhid, T, M:) or the inf. n. specially signifies the following God's revealed Scriptures, sometimes by reading, or perusing, or by reciting, and sometimes by conforming therewith [as well as by reading, &c., but not otherwise, for] every tilaAwap is qiraMCap, but the reverse is not the case. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [You say also, talaA Ealayohi He recited, or related, to him a narrative &c.: see Kur v. 30, &c.] And fulaAnN yatoluw EalaI fulaAnK, and yaquwlu Ealayohi, Such a one lies, or says what is false, against such a one. (TA.) waQtRabaEuwA maA tatoluwAlXRayaATiynu, in the Kur ii. 96, means [And they followed] what the devils related, or rehearsed, ('Atà, T,) or spoke; (A'Obeyd, T;) or, what the devils of the Jinn, or of mankind, or of both, read, or recited, or what they followed, of the writings of enchantment: (Bd:) some here read tutalRiI↓. (T.) Hence the saying, laA darayota walaA talayota: (T:) or, accord. to Yoo, it is wlA Oatolayota↓: (T, S:) and others say that it is wlA QYotalayota, from Oalawotu. (T. [See these three readings explained in the latter part of the first paragraph of art. Alw.])

He remained behind, or held back. (IAar, ISk, T.) You say, talaA baEoda qawomihi He held back, or lagged behind, after his people, or company, and remained. (TA.) And talawotuhu, (AZ, A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) and talawotu Eanohu, (AZ, T, M, K,) aor.
taluwa
, (AZ, T,) inf. n. tuluwRN, (AZ, T, M,) I left him, and held back from going with him: (AZ, T:) I held back from him, or from aiding him, and left him: (AZ, A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (K.)
He bought a tilow, meaning the young one of a mule. (IAar, T, K.)

taliyato liI mino HaqRiI taliyRapN, and tulaAwapN, aor.
talawa
, (ISk, S,) inf. n. talFA, (TA,) There remained to me, of my right, or due, a remainder. (ISk, S.) And taliyato liI Einodahu taliyRapN There remained to me, with him, or there remained owing to me by him, a remainder. (As, T.) And taliIa mina AlXRahori kacaA, (M, K,) inf. n. talFA, (M,) There remained, of the month, such a portion. (M, K.)
2: see 1, in two places.
huwa yutalRaI baqiyRapa HaAjatihi He demands, and seeks to obtain, the remainder of that which he wants. (T.)
tlRI SalaAtahu, (T, M, K,) inf. n. tatoliyapN, (K,) He made his prayer to be followed by other prayer: (T:) or he made his prescribed prayer to be followed by supererogatory prayer. (Sh, M, K.)

tlRIi, inf. n. as above, [is also said to signify] He stood erect for
prayer. (TA. [But see mitalRN, in art. tl.]
Also He accomplished, or fulfilled, his vow. (IAar, M, K.)
And He was at the last gasp. (AZ, S, M, K.)
See also 4.

3. tAlAhu, inf. n. mutaAlaApN, i. q. raAsalahu [meaning, fiI AlginaMCi, i. e. He relieved him, or aided him, in singing, by taking up the strain when the latter was unable to prolong his voice sufficiently for the accomplishing of the cadence; or he did so with a high voice: see mutaAlK, below]. (TA.)

4. Oatolayotuhu UiyRaAhu I made him to follow him; or, it to follow it. (M, K.) Hence, (TA,) AtlAhu QllRehu OaTofaAlFA God made him, or may God make him, to have little children following him. (S, TA.) And Oatolato She (a camel) had her young one following her: (S, K:) whence the saying, laA darayota walaA Oatolayota; accord. to Yoo: (S:) but see 1, where two other readings are mentioned, with a reference to the explanations.

[Hence also,] Oatolayotuhu I preceded him, outwent him, outstripped him, or got before him. (S.) And maA zilotu Oatoluwhu HatRaI Oatolayotuhu I ceased not to follow him until I became before him. (S.)
Oatolayotu HaqRiI Einodahu I left a remainder of my due with him. (S, K.) And Oatolayotu Einodahu talyRapF I left with him a remainder (T, M) of a thing, or of a debt, or of a needful thing. (M.)
Oatolayotuhu EalaI fulaAnK I referred him, or turned him over, for the payment of what was owing to him, to such a one, transferring the responsibility for the debt to the latter. (T, S, * K. *)

AtlAhu cimRapF He gave him a bond, or an obligation, whereby he became responsible for his safety: (S, K:) and AtlAhu alone (T, M, K) signifies the same; (T;) he gave him what is termed talaMC, (M, K,) i. e. cimRapF, (K,) or jiwaArFA, (M, K,) and meaning also an arrow on which was written his (the giver's) name, (K, * TA,) in order that, when he went to a tribe, he might show it to them, and they would not harm him: (TA:) and AtlAhu sahomFA (assumed tropical:) he gave him an arrow whereby to demand protection, (M, K, TA,) in order that he might not be harmed: and AtlAhu naEolFA he gave him a sandal for that purpose: (TA:) and it means (tropical:) he made him his tilow [or follower], and his companion. (TA.) tlRI↓, also, signifies, like OatolaI, He gave him his bond, or obligation, by which he became responsible for his safety. (TA.)
5. ttlRI He sought repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, or by degrees, (T, S, M, K,) to obtain his right, or due, until he received it fully, or wholly, (T, S,) or to obtain a thing. (M, K.)
He collected much wealth. (IAar, T.)
tatalRayotu HaqRiI Einodahu I left with him, or in his possession, somewhat remaining of my right, or due. (IAar, T.)
Somewhat remained of his debt. (IAar, T.)
6. tataAlati AlOumuwru The things, or events, were consecutive; they followed one another. (M, K.) And jaMCati Alxayolu tataAliyFA The horses, or horsemen, came consecutively. (S.)
10. AsttlAhu AlXRaIoCa He, or it, invited him to follow the thing. (M, K.)
Aisotatolayotu fulaAnFA I made such a one to follow me. (IAar, T.)
And I looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, such a one. (IAar, T.)
AsttlI fulaAnFA also signifies (tropical:) He sought, or demanded, of such a one, the arrow of protection [called talaMC, q. v.]. (TA.)
talFA: see taliyRapN.

tilowN A thing that follows another thing: (K:) and a follower of another man. (TA.) See also tilowu AlXRaIoCi taAlK means That which follows the thing: (S:) and hecaA tilowu hecaA This is what follows this. (M.) [Hence,] tilowu AlnRaAqapi The she-camel's young one that follows her: (S:) and tilowN [alone] a ewe's, or she-goat's, (M,) or she-camel's, (K,) young one when weaned, and following the mother; pl. OatolaMCN; and fem. with p: (M, K:) and the young one of the ass; (M, K;) because he follows his mother: (M:) and the young one of a mule: (IAar, T, K:) and, accord. to En-Nadr, a kid, and a lamb, that has become large in the stomach or belly (AstkrX) and in no need of his mother; fem. with p: (T:) or the fem. signifies a she-kid that has passed beyond the limit of those that are termed OajofaAr [pl. of jaforN, q. v.], (M, K,) until she has completed a year [from her birth] and so become a jacaE. (M.) And a tilowap of sheep or goats is One that is brought forth, or that brings forth, [the verb is tunotaju, which has both of these meanings,] before the SafariyRap [q. v.]. (S, K.)
Also High, or lofty. (K.) One says, UinRahu latilowu AlmiqodaAri Verily he, or it, is high, or lofty, in measure. (TA.)

talaMCN A bond, or an obligation, by which one becomes responsible for the safety of another: (S, M, K:) and an arrow upon which the giver writes his name, (M, K, [in the CK, AlmatoliIo is erroneously put for AlmutoliI,]) and which he gives to a man, who, when he goes to a tribe, and shows it to them, passes unmolested: (M:) and, accord. to IAmb, responsibility, or suretiship. (TA.)
Also The transfer of a debt, or of a claim, by shifting the responsibility from one person to another. (Z, TA.)
taluwRN A man incessantly following: (IAar, M, K:) not mentioned by Yaakoob among the instances of this measure which he has limited; as HasuwRN and fasuwRN. (M.)
taliIRN [accord. to the CK, erroneously, tiloIN,] Using many oaths (kaviyru AlOayomaAni): and Having much wealth. (IAar, T, K.)

taliyRapN [accord. to the CK, erroneously, tiloyapq,] and tulaAwapN↓ (ISk, T, S, M, K) and talFA↓ (M, TA) A remainder (ISk, T, S, M, K) of a thing, (M,) or of a right or due, (ISk, S,) or of a debt, (S, M, K,) and of a thing wanted, (ISk and T in explanation of the second word, and M,) &c. (K.) One says also, cahabato taliyRapu AlXRabaAbi (tropical:) The remainder of youthfulness, or youthful vigour, departed. (TA.) And fulaAnN taliyRapu AlOaHoraAri (tropical:) [Such a one is the last remaining of the ingenuous]. (TA.)
waqaEa kacaA taliyRapa kacaA Such a thing happened after such a thing. (M.)
tulaAwapN: see taliyRapN.
talawRaI A kind of boat: (M, K:) of the measure faEawRalN, (M, TA,) or faEalowalN: (TA:) so called because it follows the larger vessel: mentioned by Aboo-'Alee in the Tedhkireh. (M.)
talRaMCN liloquroMni One who reads, peruses, or recites, the Kur-án, or who follows it, or acts according to it, much, or often. (Mgh.)
taAlK act. part. n. of talaA; Following; going, or walking, behind, or after; [immediately, or without intervention; either in reality, or only in effect; (see 1;)] (T, Msb;) as also tilowN↓. (Msb.)
AltRaAliI The fourth of the ten horses that are started together in a race. (TA voce sukRayot &c., and Ham p. 46.)
Also, (Sh, TA voce mijodaHN,) and taAliI AlnRajomK [meaning The follower of the Pleiades], (Kzw,) the star called AldRabaraAnu. (Sh, Kzw.)

And taAliyaAtu AlnRujuwmi The last of the stars; [app. the last that are seen in the morningtwilight;] (TA;) as also AltRawaAliI. (M, TA.) [taAliyaAtN and tawaAl are both pls. of taAliyapN, fem. of taAlK.]
AltRawaAliI also signifies The last of women journeying in vehicles upon camels; (M, K;) and in like manner, of camels. (M.)

Also Hinder parts, posteriors, or rumps: and the hinder parts of horses: or (of a horse, M) the tail and hind legs. (M, K.) One says, UinRahu laHaviyvu AltRawaAliI and sariyEu AltRawaAliI [app. meaning Verily he is quick in the hind legs]. (M.) And the Arabs say, layosa hawaAdiI Alxayoli kaAltRawaAliI, i. e., The necks of horses are not like their hinder parts. (TA.)
faAltRaAlayAti cikorFA [in the Kur xxxvii. 3] means And those angels, or angels and others, that recite the praise of God. (M.)
mutolK and mutoliyapN (T, M) A mother, (T,) or a she-camel, and a female wild animal, (M,) having her young one following her: pl. mataAlK. (T, M.)

Also, both sings., A she-camel that brings forth in the last portion of the breeding-time: or the latter sing. signifies one that is late in bringing forth; and the former sing. has the first of the meanings explained in this paragraph: (M:) or, as some say, the latter sing. signifies one that has become heavy by pregnancy, so that the head of her fœtus has turned towards the tail and the vulva; a meaning not agreeing with the derivation: (IJ, M:) or, as some say, this word signifies [simply] pregnant: (Ham p. 688:) accord. to El-Báhilee, the pl. signifies she-camels of which some have brought forth, and others have not. (TA.) You say, Uibiluhumo mataAlK, meaning Their camels have not brought forth until the season called the Sayof, (K, TA,) which is the last part of the breeding-time. (TA.)

mutaAlK One who relieves, or aids, another, in singing, and in work, by taking up the strain, or the work, when the latter is unable to continue it: (IAar, T:) or one who so relieves, or aids, the singer, with a high voice: (S, TA:) and one who
sings to camels to urge them on, or excite them. (TA.)

musotatolK [act. part. n. of 10, q. v. It is said in the T to have a signification derived from talaMCN in the last of the senses assigned to the latter word above; so that it seems to mean Seeking, or demanding, the transfer of a debt, or claim, or the like, by shifting the responsibility from one person to another].
1. talayotuhu: see talawotuhu.
taliIRN &c.: see art. tlw.

1. tamRa AlXRaIoCu, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) aor.
tamima
, (T, M, K,) inf. n. tamaAmN, (T, S,) or timaAmN, (M,) or both, and tumaAmN, (K,) and tamaAmapN (M, K) and timaAmapN, (K,) and tmRu and tamRN and tumRN, (M, K,) of which last three forms the first is said to be the most chaste, (TA,) [The thing was, or became, complete, entire, whole, or full; i. e., without, or free from, deficiency: and sometimes, the thing was, or became, consummate, or perfect; which latter signification is more properly expressed by kamala:] accord. to the author of the K, as is shown in art. kml, and accord. to some others, tamaAmN and kamaAlN are syn.; but several authors make a distinction between them: the former is said to signify a thing's being, or becoming, without, or free from, deficiency; and the latter, to signify tmAm and something more, as, for instance, goodliness, and excellence, essential or accidental; though each is sometimes used in the sense of the other: or, as some say, the former necessarily implies previous deficiency; but the latter does not: (MF, TA:) or, accord. to El-Harállee, the latter signifies the attaining to the utmost point, or degree, in every respect: or, as Ibn-El-Kemál says, when one says of a thing kamala, he means that what was desired of it became realized. (TA.) [See also tamaAmN, below.] You say, tamRa xaloquhu [His make, or formation, was, or became, complete, or perfect; he (a child or the like, and a man,) was, or became, fully formed or developed, or complete in his members; and he (a man) was, or became, full-grown]: (TA:) [whence, probably,] tamRa AlXRaIoCu [as meaning] The thing became strong and hard. (Msb.) And tamRa Alqamaru, (T, S, Msb,) or AtmR↓, (M, K,) The moon became full, so that it shone brightly. (M, K) And, of her who is pregnant, tamRato OayRaAmu HamolihaA [The days of her gestation became complete]. (S.)
tamRa UilaI kacaA He reached, attained, arrived at, or came to, such a thing; as, for instance, eminence or nobility, or the means of acquiring eminence or nobility. (TA.)
tamRa UilaI mawoDiEi kacaA, and Uilayohi AtmR↓, He repaired, or betook himself, to, or towards, such a place; he went to it. (Har p. 508.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,

L.foreign: fabaAta bijamoEK vumRa tamRa UilaI minFI

sense.s: [which may be rendered And he passed the night in Jema (a name of El-Muzdelifeh): then he repaired, or went, to Minè; there completing the ceremonies of the pilgrimage; wherefore ISd says,] I think that, by tmR, [or rather tmR AlI mnI,] he means he completed his pilgrimage. (M.)
tamRa bihi, and tamRa Ealayohi: see their syn. AtmRhu (4).
[Hence,] tamRa Ealayohi He performed it, or executed it; he accomplished it; namely, an affair; a fast; a purpose, or an intention. (Mgh.)

And He persevered in it; (Mgh, TA;) as also tamama Ealayohi, without teshdeed, as in the phrase Uino tamamato EalaI maA Ouriydu [If she persevere in what I desire], occurring in a trad.; but IAth says that the verb here means tamRamato↓. (TA.) You say, tamRa EalaI AlUbaMCi He persevered in refusal, or dislike, or disapproval. (Mgh.)
tumRa It was broken. (T.)
And i. q. blg [app. buliga, i. e. He was jaded, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied]. (T.)
2. tamRamahu: see its syn. AtmRhu; and see also 1, near the end of the paragraph.
He, or it, destroyed it; made it to reach its appointed term of duration. (Sh, T, K.)

tamRamahumo He gave them the share of their arrow in the game called Almayosir; (IAar, M, K;) i. e. he gave them to eat the flesh which was their share. (M.) Accord. to Lh, AltRatomiymu in the game called Almysr signifies A man's taking what has remained, so as to complete the shares, or make up their full number, when the players have diminished from the slaughtered camel [by taking their shares]. (T.)
tRmm EalaI AljariyHi (tropical:) He hastened and completed the slaughter of the wounded man: or made his slaughter sure, or certain. (M, K, TA.)

tRmm Alkasoru, (M, K,) and ttmRm↓, (M, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, tamRa, (TA,) [in the CK, tRmm again,] i. e. [The fracture, or the broken bone, or simply the bone,] cracked, without separating (walamo yabino): or cracked, and then separated. (M, K.) You say, tamRama Alkasora fatamRama and tatamRama↓ [He, or it, completed the fracture, or cracked the broken bone, or the bone, and it cracked, &c.]. (M.) And ZalaEa fulaAnN vumRa tatamRama↓, i. e. [Such a one limped, or halted, or was slightly lame: then] his lameness became complete by fracture: from tumRa signifying “ it was broken: ” (T:) [or tatamRama signifies his lameness became complete by an increased fracture, after he had had a fracture with which he was able to walk: this is what is meant by the following loose explanation:] AltRatamRumu mano kaAna bihi kasorN yamoXiI bihi vumRa OabatRa fatatamRama. (K. [In the CK, AabRata is here erroneously put for OabatRa.])
tmRm Alamawoluwda He hung tamaAYim, (Th, M,) or a tamiymap, (K,) upon the new-born child, or young infant. (Th, M, K.)
tamRamotu Eanohu AlEayona I repelled from him the evil eye by hanging [upon him] the tamiymap. (A, TA.)

tmRm also signifies He became, in the inclination of his mind, (Lth, T, M, K,) and in his opinion, and his place of abode or settlement, (Lth, T, K,) as one of the tribe of Temeem; (Lth, T, M, K;) as also ttmRm↓; (K, TA; [in the CK, tmRm again;]) or accord. to analogy it would be ttmRm, like tmDRr and tnzRr. (T.) And He asserted himself to be related to the tribe of Temeem. (M.)
3. mutaAmRpN [inf. n. of taAmRa] The vying, or contending, with another in completeness, or perfection. (KL.) [You say, tAmRhu He vied, or contended, with him &c.]
4. AtmR, said of the moon: see 1.
Said of a plant, It became tall and full-grown; or became of its full height, and blossomed. (M, K.)
OatamRato, said of one that is pregnant, She completed the days of her gestation: (S:) or, said of a woman and of a she-camel, (M,) she became near to bringing forth. (M, K.)
AtRm UilaI mawoDiEi kacaA: see 1.

AtmR AlXRaIoCa, (S, M, K,) or AlOamora, (Mgh,) and AtmR bihi, (M,) inf. n. UitomaAmN; (TA;) and tmRmhu↓, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. tatomiymN and tatimRapN; (T, TA;) and AsttmRhu↓; (S, Mgh, K;) and bihi tamRa↓, and Ealayohi tamRa↓; (M, K;) signify the same; (S Mgh;) i. e. jaEalahu taAmRaA (M in explanation of all but the last, and K in explanation of all that are mentioned therein,) and Oakomalahu (M in explanation of the last) [He made the thing, or the affair, complete, entire, whole, or full; i. e., without, or free from, deficiency; he completed it: and sometimes, he consummated, or perfected, it]. waOatimRuw AlHajRa waAlEumorapa, in the Kur [ii. 192], means And perform ye, or accomplish ye, completely, the rites and ceremonies [of the pilgrimage and the minor pilgrimage]; (M, * Bd;) accord. to some: or, as some say, UitomaAmu AlHajRi means that the money, or the like, that one expends in performing the pilgrimage should be lawfully obtained, and that one should refrain from doing what God has forbidden. (M.) And faOatamRahunRa, in the Kur [ii. 118], means And he performed them, or accomplished them, completely, (Bd, Jel,) and rightly: (Bd:) or he did according to them. (Fr, TA.)

AtmRhu He gave him what are termed timam, pl. of timRapN, and meaning jizaz [explained below, voce timRapN], (M, TA,) in order that he might complete therewith his web. (TA.) [In consequence of its being misplaced in the K, this is there made to signify He gave him a timR, meaning a faOos or a misoHaAp.]
5: see 2, in four places.

6. tataAmRuwA They came, [and also, accord. to Golius, app. on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, they drank,] all of them, and were complete. (S, K.) One says, AijotamaEuwA fatataAmRuwA EaXarapF [They collected themselves together, and came, all of them, making altogether ten]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., tataAmRato Uilayohi qurayoXN, i. e. Kureysh obeyed his call, and came to him, all of them, following one another. (TA.)
10. AsttmRhu: see 4.
AsttRm AlnRiEomapa He asked for the completion of the benefit, or boon, or favour. (M, K.)

He sought, demanded, or requested, of him what are termed timRm, pl. of timRapN, and meaning jizaz [explained below, voce timRapN], (M, TA,) in order that he might complete therewith his web. (TA.) [In consequence of its being misplaced in the K, this is there made to signify He sought, demanded, or requested, of him a timR, meaning a faOos or a misoHaAp.]

R. Q. 1. tamotamapN is the inf. n. of tamotama, (Msb,) and signifies The reiterating in uttering the letter t: (Mbr, Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán, ” T, S, Msb:) [if so, syn. with taOotaOapN:] or the tongue's pronouncing indistinctly, missing the place of the letter, [i. e. the place of its pronunciation in the organs of speech,] and recurring to an utterance like t and m, though this be not distinct: (Lth, T:) or the making the speech [or tongue] to revert [repeatedly] to t and m: (M, K:) or the jabbering, or hurrying in one's speech, so as hardly, or not at all, to make a person understand: (M:) or the uttering in such a manner that one's speech proceeds rapidly to the roof of his mouth. (M, K.)
tamRN an inf. n. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above. (M, K.) See tamaAmN, in two places.
See also timRapN.
tumRN an inf. n. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above. (M, K.) See tamaAmN, in two places.
timRN an inf. n. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above. (M, K.) See tamaAmN, in five places:
and taAmRN, in three places.
Also i. q. faOosN [app. here meaning A kind of hoe]: (IAar, T, K:) or i. q. misoHaApN [a spade, or a shovel]: (K:) pl. timamapN (IAar, T,) or timamN. (So in the TA.)
tumRapN: see what next follows, in two places.

timRapN (M, K) and tumRapN↓ (TA) [the former written in the CK tamRapN] sings. of timamN (M, K, TA) and tumamN, (K, TA,) or tamamN↓, which [ISd says] I think to be a quasi-pl. n., (M,) or tamRN↓ is the quasipl. n.: (K:) these, i. e. the pls. and quasi-pl. n., signify Shorn crops (jizaz [in the CK jizar, for which Golius appears to have found Hiroz, for he has rendered it by “ amuletum, ” and Freytag has done the same,]) of XaEar [meaning goats' hair], and of camels' hair, and of wool, (M, K, TA,) of that wherewith a woman [or a man] completes her [or his] web: (TA:) and tumRapN↓ signifies what is given, of wool, or camel's hair, [or goats' hair,] (S, TA, [and mentioned also in the K, but there, by misplacement, made to relate to timRN instead of timRapN,]) for a man to complete therewith the weaving of his kisaMC; (S;) as also tumRaI↓. (K, * TA.)
tumRaI: see timRapN.
tamamN: see taAmRN, in four places:
and see also timRapN.

tamaAmN (T, S, K) and timaAmN↓ (M, K) and tumaAmN↓ (K) inf. ns. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above; (T, S, M, K;) as also timRN↓ and tamRN↓ and tumRN↓. (M, K.) [Hence,] waladatohu litimRK↓ and litimaAmK↓ and litamaAmK She brought him forth at the completion of formation; (K, TA;) i. e., when his formation was complete: (TA:) [or, at the completion of gestation:] and, accord. to As, waladatohu AltRamaAma, with the art. Al; not indeterminate, except in poetry. (IB, TA.) And waladato litamaAmK and litimaAmK↓ [She brought forth at the completion of formation; or, of gestation]. (S.) And Oaloqati Alwalada ligayori tamaAmK and timaAmK↓ [She cast the child at a period not that of the completion of formation; or, of gestation; i. e., prematurely]. (Msb.) And wulida Almawoluwdu litamaAmK and litimaAmK↓ [The infant was born at the completion of formation; or, of gestation]. (T, * S.) And wulida Alwaladu litamaAmi AlHamoli and AlHamoli litimaAmi↓ [The child was born at the completion of gestation]. (Msb.) [These exs., and others following, show that an assertion of IDrd, mentioned in the M, namely, that one says, wulida AlgulaAmu litimRK↓ and litimaAmK↓, and badoru timaAmK↓, and that in every other case it is tamaAm, with fet-h, requires consideration.] You say also, badoru tamaAmK and timaAmK↓ [lit. The full moon of completion]: and badorN timaAmN↓ [lit. A complete full moon]: all meaning the moon, or a moon, when it is full, so that it shines brightly: (M, K:) and qamarN tamaAmN and timaAmN↓ A complete, or full, moon. (S.) And layolapu AltRamaAmi and layolapu tamaAmi Alqamari, with fet-h to the t, (ISh, T,) or ↓, laylapu AltRimaAmi with kesr, [which seems to be at variance with general usage,] and sometimes with fet-h, (Msb,) [The night of the completion of the moon; i. e.] the night of the full moon; (ISh, T, Msb;) which is the thirteenth night; (ISh, T;) or the fourteenth. (T.) And layolu AltRimaAmi↓, with kesr only, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) thus distinguished from what next precedes, (ISh, T,) as also layolu timaAmK↓, and in like manner, layolN timaAmN↓ (T) and layolN timaAmiIRN↓, (T, K,) The longest night of the year; (Lth, T, S;) the longest night of winter; (As, ISh, T, M, K;) that in which our Lord Jesus was born: (As, T:) or each of three nights of which no deficiency is apparent: (Lth, T, M, K:) or the night that is from thirteen to fifteen hours in length: (Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee, T:) or the night that is twelve hours or more in length: (AA, T, M, K:) and any night that is long, or tedious, to one, and in which one does not sleep, is called layolapu AltRimaAmi↓, or said to be like the night thus called. (IAar, T.) And AlXRahori ruYiIa AlhilaAlu litimRi↓ [The new moon was seen at the completion of the month; showing that another month was commencing]. (T.) And OabaI qaAYiluhaA UilRaA timRFA↓ and tamRFA↓ and tumRFA↓, (S, M,) three dial. vars., of which the first is the most chaste, i. e., tamaAmFA [meaning The sayer thereof refused, or did not consent to, aught save completion]; he executed, or accomplished, or kept to, his saying; he did not go back from it. (S, TA.)

tamaAmN (with fet-h only, AZ, AAF, M) also signifies The complement of a thing; the supplement thereof; the thing by the addition of which is effected the completion or perfection of a thing; (AZ, T, AAF, M, K;) and so tamaAmapN↓ (M, K) and tatimRapN↓. (T, M, K.) You say, hecihi AldRaraAhimu tamaAmu hecihi AlmiAYapi, and hch AlmAYp tatimRapu↓, These dirhems are the complement of this hundred; or, what complete this hundred. (T.) [And tatimRapu↓ kitaAbK The supplement of, or to, a book.]
See also taAmRN, in two places.
tumaAmN: see tamaAmN, first sentence.
timaAmN: see tamaAmN, throughout the greater part of the paragraph:
and see also taAmRN.

tamiymN Strong; firm; hard: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K:) or strong in make, or formation: (TA:) or complete, or perfect, in make, or formation, and strong: (M:) applied to a man and to a horse: (M, TA:) fem. with p. (TA.) See also taAmRN.
Also Tall; (T;) applied to a man. (TA.)
See also tamiymapN.
tamaAmapN: see tamaAmN, near the end of the paragraph.
tumaAmapN A remainder, or remaining portion, (K,) of anything. (TA.)

tamiymapN A kind of amulet (EuwcapN, T, S) which is hung upon a human being; forbidden to be worn: (S:) or a kind of bead: (S, Mgh:) erroneously imagined by some to be the same as maEaAcapN: (El- Kutabee, Mgh:) but as to the maEaAcaAt that are inscribed with something from the Kur-án, or with the names of God, in these there is no harm: (S, Mgh:) a speckled bead, black speckled with white, or the reverse, which is strung upon a thong, and tied to the neck: (M, K:) sing. of tamaAYimu and [n. un. of] tamiymN↓: (T, M, K:) tamaAYimu signifies certain beads which the Arabs of the desert used to hang upon their children, to repel, as they asserted, the evil eye: (T, Mgh:) or the tamiymap is, accord. to some, a necklace (qilaAdap) upon which are put thongs and amulets (Euwac): (M:) or a necklace (qilaAdap) of thongs: and is sometimes applied to the amulet (Euwcap) that is hung upon the necks of children: (T:) but he who makes tmAYm to signify thongs is in error: El-Farezdak uses the phrase suyuwru AltRamaAYimi because they are beads which are perforated, and into which are inserted thongs or strings whereby they are suspended: (T, Mgh:) Az says, I have not found among the Arabs of the desert any difference of opinion respecting the tmymp, as to its being the bead itself: (TA:) but accord. to En-Nakha'ee, the Prophet disapproved of everything hung upon a child or grown person, and said that all such things were tmAYm: (Mgh:) the tmymp is [said to be] thus called because by it the condition of the child is rendered complete. (Har p. 22.)
timaAmiIRN: see tamaAmN.

tamotaAmN One whose utterance is such as is termed tamotamapN: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) [see R. Q. 1: accord. to most authorities,] one who reiterates in uttering the letter t: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or, accord. to AZ, one who jabbers, or hurries in his speech, so as not to make another understand: (Mgh, Msb:) fem. with p. (M, K.)

taAmRN [part. n. of 1 in the first of the senses explained above]: (T, M, K, &c.:) Complete, entire, whole, or full; without, or free from, deficiency: and consummate, or perfect: (MF, TA:) as also tamaAmN↓, [which see above,] (M, * KL,) [and timaAmN↓,
of which see three exs. voce tamaAmN,] and timRN↓, (Kh, T, Har p. 82,) and tamamN↓. (TA.) Thus taAmRu Alxaloqi signifies Complete, or perfect, in make, or formation; without any deficiency in his members; applied to a man; (MF, TA;) [and, thus applied, signifying also full-grown, as does, sometimes, taAmRN alone: and likewise applied to a new-born child, meaning fully formed or developed:] and tamiymN↓ signifies the same, (M, K,) applied to a man and to a horse, (M,) and tamamN↓ also; and in like manner is used the phrase xaloqN tamamN↓ [a complete, or perfect, make or formation]. (TA.)

jacaEN taAmRN [applied to a goat] signifies That has completed the time in which he is termed jacaE, and attained to that in which he is termed tayos. (TA.) And tamamN↓ is applied to a bull, or an ox, That is in the stage of growth next before that in which all his teeth are grown; in which latter stage he is termed EamamN. (L voce EaDobN, on the authority of Et-Táïfee.) You say also kalimapN taAmRapN, and daEowahN taAmRapN; [meaning A perfect, or faultless, sentence, and oath;] using the epithet tAmRp in these instances because of the mention of God therein; for which reason there may not be in aught of either of them any deficiency or defect. (TA.) And jaEalahu timRFA↓ i. e. tamaAmFA↓ [He made it complete, or perfect]. (M.) And jaEalotuhu laka timRFA↓ I made it, or have made it, to be thine, or I assigned it, or have assigned it, to thee, completely, or wholly. (T.)
[Hence, fiEolN taAmRN meaning A complete, i. e. an attributive, verb: opposed to fiEolN naAqiSN.]
tatimRapN: see tamaAmN, in three places, at the close of the paragraph.
mutamRN The place of cutting, or termination, (munoqaTaE, in the CK munoqaTiE,) of the vein (Eiroq [app. meaning chord]) of the navel. (K.)

mutimRN, applied to one that is pregnant, (S,) or to a woman, (M, TA,) and a she-camel, (M,) That has completed the days of her gestation: (S:) or that is near to bringing forth: (M:) or that is at the point of bringing forth. (TA.)

mutamRimN One whose arrow wins time after time [in the game called Almayosir], and who feeds the poor with the flesh [of the camel which constitutes the shares] thereof: (M, K:) or who, when players in the game called Almysr have diminished the slaughtered camel [by taking their shares], takes what has remained, so as to complete the shares, or make up their full number. (K. [See 2. In the CK, naqaSa AiyosAra jazuwori Almayosiri is erroneously put for naqaSa OayosaArN jazuwra Almayosiri.])
AljahaAlapu AlmusotatamRapu Consummate ignorance: improperly written AlmusotatimRapu, though this latter is explainable [as meaning that completes the extent to which it can go, or the like]. (Mgh.)
musotatimRN One who seeks, demands, or requests, wool, or camels' hair, to complete therewith the weaving of his kisaMC: so in a poem of Aboo-Duwád, (S,) where he says,

L.foreign: fahoIa kaAlbayoDi fiI AlOadaAHiIRi laA yuwo

sense.s: i. e., And they (referring to certain camels) are, in respect of the care that is taken of them, and in smoothness, like the eggs [in the places where the ostrich has deposited them in the sand]; there may not be found upon them to be given from them, to one who demands a timRap, [even so much as] a tie for a water-skin; for they have become fat, and cast their hair. (TA.)

1. tamara, (S, M, K, &c.,) aor.
tamura
, (M, TA,) or
tamira
, (Msb,) inf. n. tamorN; (S, Msb, K;) and tmRr↓, (M, K,) inf. n. tatomiyrN; (TA;) and Atmr↓; (M, K;) He fed people with, or gave them to eat, tamor [or dried dates]. (S, M, Msb, K.)
2. tmRr, inf. n. tatomiyrN, He dried (S, M, K) dates. (S.)

(tropical:) He dried flesh-meat: (T, S:) or he cut flesh-meat into small pieces, (M, A, * IAth, K,) like dates, (IAth,) and dried it. (M, A, IAth, K.) It is said in a trad., kaAna laA yaraI biAltRatomiyri baOosFA (tropical:) He used not to see any harm in cutting flesh-meat into small pieces, like dates, and drying it: meaning, in a Mohrim's thus preparing flesh-meat for travelling-provision; or in one's drying the flesh of wild animals before the state of ihrám. (IAth.)
See also 1:
and 4, in two places.
4. Atmr He possessed many, or a large quantity of, tamor [or dried dates]. (S, M, K.)
Atmrt AlnRaxolapu, (T, M, A, K,) and tmRrt↓, (M, K,) The palm-tree bore tamor [or dry dates]: (M, K:) or had ripe dates upon it. (K.)
Atmr AlrRuTabu; (T, K;) and tmRr↓, inf. n. tatomiyrN; (K;) The ripe dates became in the state in which they are termed tamor. (K.)
See also 1.
5. ttmRr It (flesh-meat) was cut into strips, or small pieces, and dried. (A.)

tamorN, a coll. gen. n.; (S, A;) masc. in one dial. and fem. in another [like other nouns of the same class]; (Msb;) Dates, or the fruit of the palmtree: (M:) or dried dates, like zabiybN as applied to grapes, by general consent of the lexicologists: (Mgh, Msb:) the dates are left upon the palmtree, after they have become ripe, until they are dry, or nearly so, when they are cut, and left in the sun to dry thoroughly; and sometimes, as AHát says, the fruit of the palm-tree is cut when full-grown but unripe, to lighten the tree, or from fear of theft, and left until it becomes tamor: (Msb:) the n. un. is with p: and the pl. of tamorN is tumuwrN and tumoraAnN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) meaning sorts or varieties [of tamor]; for a coll. gen. n. has not a pl. in the proper sense: (S:) and in like manner the dual tamoraAni means two sorts [of tamor]: (Sb cited in the M in art. bsr:) the pl. of tamorapN is tamaraAtN. (S, K.) [See also busorN.] Hence the prov., OaEoTi OaxaAka tamorapF faUino OabaI fajamorapF [Give thou thy brother a dried date; and if he refuse it, a live coal]. (A, TA.) And AltRamoru biAlsRawiyqi [Dried dates with meal of parched barley or wheat] is another prov., used in allusion to requital. (Lh.) And one says, wajada Einodahu tamorapa AlguraAbi, meaning (tropical:) He found with him, or at his abode, what he approved. (A.) And nafosuhu tamorapN bikacaA (tropical:) His mind is pleased, or agreeably affected, with, or by, such a thing; or consents to such a thing. (A, K. * [Accord. to the TA, it is here like fariHapN; but this seems to be true as to the meaning; not as to the form of the word. See also art. vmr, voce vamirN.]) And daEoniI UinRa nafosiI gayoru tamorapK (tropical:) [Leave thou me, or let me alone: verily my mind is not pleased, or happy]. (A.)
tamorN hinodiIRN [The fruit of the tamarindtree; thus called in the present day;] i. q. HumarN and HawomarN. (K in art. Hmr.)
tamoriIRN One who loves tamor [or dried dates]. (S, A, K.)
tamRaArN A seller of tamor [or dried dates]. (S, A, K.)

taAmirN Possessing tamor [or dried dates]; (S, M, A, Msb;) like laAbinN “ possessing milk: ” (S, Msb:) or taAmirN, (Lh, M, K,) or mutomirN↓, (S, A,) signifies possessing many, or a large quantity of, tamor: (Lh, S, M, A, K:) the former of these two words is held by ISd to be a possessive epithet: (TA:) and sometimes it may signify feeding people with, or giving them to eat, tamor. (S, TA.)
taAmuwrN and taAmuwrapN and tuwmuwrN and tuwmuriIRN &c.: see art. Amr.
mutomirN: see taAmirN.
matomuwrN Furnished with tamor [or dried dates] for travelling-provision. (S, K.)

1. tamaka, aor.
tamuka
(S, K) and
tamika
, (K,) inf. n. tamukN (S, K) and tumuwkN, (K,) It (a camel's hump) was, or became, tall, or long and high: (S, K:) it was, or became, juicy, and compact, (O, K,) and plump. (M, TA.)
[Hence,] tamaka fiyhi AlHusonu [app. (assumed tropical:) Beauty became fully developed, or consummate, in him]. (TA.)

4. Atmk sanaAmahu [It made his (a camel's) hump to become tall, or long and high, or juicy and compact, and plump]; said of the [herbage called] rabiyE. (A, TA.) And Atmk AlnRaAqapa It (herbage) made the she-camel fat. (IDrd, K.)
taAmikN, applied to a camel's hump, Tall, or long and high: (S, TA:) or high: or juicy, and compact, and plump: (TA:) or a camel's hump, in whatever state it be. (M, K.)
A she-camel having a large hump: (ISd, K:) pl. tawaAmiku. (TA.)
A high, or lofty, building. (TA.)
You say also, UinRahu lataAmiku AljamaAli [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is a person of fully-developed, or consummate, beauty]. (TA.)
And Xarafuka taAmikN waUiqobaAluka saAmikN (tropical:) [Thy nobility is lofty, and thy good fortune is high]. (A, TA.)

tamRuwzu [sometimes written tamuwzu, without tesh-deed,] The [Syrian] month [sacred, in ancient times, to the god of that name, (mentioned in Ezek. viii. 14,) corresponding to July, O. S.,] after HaziyrAnu. (S in art. Hzr.)

1. tanRa biAlmakaAni, [aor., accord. to rule,
tanina
, i. q. tanaOa,] He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (M.)
3. tAnR bayonahumaA, (K,) inf. n. mutaAnRapN, (TA,) He measured, or compared, them two together. (K.)
4. AtnR, (K,) inf. n. UitonaAnN, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote. (K.)

AtnRhu It (a disease) stunted him, (AZ, IAar, T, S, M, K,) namely, a child, or boy, (IAar, T, S, M, K,) so that he did not attain to the stature of his equals in age, (AZ, T,) or so that he did not attain to full growth. (IAar, T, S, M, K.)
R. Q. 1. tanotana [in the CK tatanRana] He (a man, IAar, T) left, or deserted, his friends, and associated with others. (IAar, T, K.)
tanRN: see tinRN.
See also a poetical citation voce tawRN.
tunRN and tunRapN The tunny-fish. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Beytár; and so in the present day; but the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is a n. un.)

tinRN A like; an equal, a match, or a fellow; (S, M, K;) as also taniynN↓; (K, TA [in the CK tiniyn];) an equal in age; (T, M;) an equal in intellect, or in weakness, or in strength, or in manliness, or manly virtue: (ISk, S:) or a companion: (M:) pl. OatonaAnN. (T, M.) You say, fulaAnN tinRu fulaAnK [Such a one is the like, or equal, &c., of such a one]. (S.) And huwa sinRuhu and tinRuhu and Hitonuhu [He is his like, or equal, &c.]. (T.) And humaA tinRaAni They two are equals in intellect, or in weakness, or in strength, or in manliness, or manly virtue. (ISk, S.) And SibowapN OatonaAnN [Boys that are like each other, or equals, &c.]. (T.) And humo OasonaAnN OatonaAnN They are equals in age. (IAar, T.)
A boy stunted by disease, (Lth, T, M,) so that he does not attain to full growth; (Lth, T;) as also tanRN↓. (M.)
Also i. q. XaxoSN [The body, or corporeal form, of a man or other thing, which one sees from a distance; or a person; an individual]. (T.)
And i. q. mivaAlN [A model; a pattern; &c.]: (T:) and tiynaAnN↓ [likewise] signifies the mvAl of a thing. (K.)
taniynN: see tinRN.

tinRiynN [in Hebr. ???] A great serpent; (K;) a kind of serpent, (Lth, T, S, M,) one of the greatest of serpents, (Lth, T,) or like the greatest thereof: (M:) it is related that a company of soldiers, on the shore of the Sea of Syria, saw a cloud divide upon the sea, and then rise, and they saw the tail of the tnRyn in a state of commotion in the fringe of the cloud: it is also related that a cloud carries the tnRyn to the country of Yájooj and Májooj [or Gog and Magog], and casts it down there, and they assemble thereupon, and eat its flesh: (T:) [these stories are fanciful accounts of the natural phenomenon called a water-spout, to which this name is applied by the Arabs in the present day: but the word is generally understood to mean a dragon: and a great sea-monster;] an aquatic animal, great in make, terrible in appearance, long and broad in the body, large in the head, having very glistening eyes, wide mouth and inside, and many teeth: it swallows many animals; the animals of the land and of the sea fear it; and when it moves, the sea becomes agitated with waves by reason of its great strength: in its first state, it is a malignant serpent, that eats what it sees of the beasts of the land; and when its mischief becomes great, God sends an angel that carries it away, and throws it to Yájooj and Májooj: it is related of one that was seen to fall, that it was found to be about two leagues in length, of a colour like that of the leopard, with scales like those of a fish, two great fins in form like those of a fish, a head like a great hill, resembling the head of a man, two long and great ears, and two round eyes; and from its neck branched forth six other necks, every one of them nearly twenty cubits long, and every one of them having a head like that of the serpent. (Kzw.) [Golius thinks it to mean The shark (“carcharias”).]

Hence, AltRinRiynu is (assumed tropical:) A certain najom [or constellation; the constellation of the Dragon]; thus named as being likened to the serpent so called; (M;) a constellation containing thirty-one stars within the figure; among which are those called AlrRaAqiSu and AlEawaAYicu and AlrRubaEu and AlcRiYobaAni &c. (Kzw, TA. *)

[Also, app., (assumed tropical:) A certain imaginary figure in the heavens, extending along the line of the nodes of a planet, which are called the dragon's head and the dragon's tail, in Arabic Aljawozaharu (from the Persian Gawozihoro), or AljawozaAharaAni, and also AlEuqodataAni, and, to distinguish each from the other, AlrRaOosu waAlcRanabu: this line is supposed by Golius to be meant by the following description; but I incline to regard it as the result of a confusion of a description of this line with a description of the zodiacal light, a phenomenon supposed to have been unnoticed by the Arabs:] a slight whiteness in the sky, (Lth, T, K,) not an asterism, (Lth, T,) the body of which is in six signs of the zodiac, and the tail, which is slender, black, and twisted, in the seventh sign: it changes place like the planets; is called in Persian haXotanobaro, (Lth, T, K,) [app. a mistranscription of hasotaburo,] in astrological computation; and is inauspicious: (Lth, T:) accord. to J, a certain place in the sky; which is a correct explanation, though said in the K to be a mistake. (TA.)
tiynaAnN: see tinRN.
Also A wolf: (K, in this art. and in art. tyn:) but used only by El-Akhtal. (TA.)

1. tanaOa, aor.
tanaAa
, inf. n. tunuwoCN, He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) bihi in it, namely, a country, or town, (S, Msb,) or a place; (M;) he settled therein: (Msb:) as also tnA, (M, Msb,) not a dial. var., but formed by substitution [of A for O], (M,) [i. e.] by suppression of the C. (Msb.)
tanaOa EalaI kacaA He kept, or adhered, to such a thing, inseparably. (TA.)
Also, inf. n. as above, He was, or became, rich, wealthy, possessed of much property. (Msb.)
tinaMCapN a subst. from tanaOa, (S, K,) meaning A remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding [in a country, or town, or place]. (TK.)

taAniYN Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, (T, Msb,) in a country, or town [&c.]; settling therein: also pronounced taAnK, by suppression of the C: (Msb:) one who remains, stays, or abides, in his country, or town; (Th, TA;) i. q. dihoqaAnN [app. as meaning a man having a fixed abode in a district of cultivated land, or in a village or town of such a district: but see below]: (Th, K, TA:) pl. tunRaMCN. (T, S, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., layosa liltRaAniYapi XaIoCN, meaning For those who remain in their abodes, and go not forth with the soldiers on expeditions against the enemy, there shall be nothing; i. e., no share of the spoil. (TA.)
Rich; wealthy; possessing much property. (Msb.) [Or A man possessing much land or other immoveable property: for this is a signification assigned to dihoqaAnN.]
tanRaArN [and tanRuwriIRN↓] A maker of ovens of the kind called tanRuwr. (M, K.)

tanRuwrN A sort of kaAnuwn [or fire-place]; (M;) the thing, (S, Msb,) or kAnwn, (K,) in which bread is baked; (S, Msb, K;) but different from the furon: (S in art. frn:) [it is a kind of oven, open at the top, in the bottom of which a fire is lighted, and in which the bread, in the form of flat cakes, is generally stuck against the sides; either portable, and made of baked clay, wide at the bottom, and narrow at the top, where it is open; and if so, the bread is sometimes stuck upon the outside, to bake; or fixed, and in this case made of baked clay likewise, or constructed of bricks; or it is a hole made in the ground, and lined with bricks or tiles or the like, against which the bread is stuck, to bake; and sometimes flesh-meat, cut into small pieces, is roasted in it, or upon it, on skewers:] such, accord. to some, is the meaning in the Kur xi. 42 and xxiii. 27; (T;) and the word is said to have the same meaning in every language; (Lth, T, M;) but this is not correct: (Ham p. 793:) it is an arabicized word; (T, M;) not genuine Arabic; (AHát, Msb;) originally Persian: (M:) [in Hebrew ???:] Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th, as is stated in Ham, ubi suprà,] says that it is of the measure tafoEuwlN from AlnRaAr, (M, and Ham ubi suprà,) or from AlnRuwr; originally tanowuwrN; (Ham;) but this is wrong: (M:) the pl. is tanaAniyru. (M, Msb.) Mo- hammad is related to have said to a man wearing a garment dyed with bastard-saffron, “ If thy garment were in the tnRwr of thy family, or beneath
their cooking-pot, it were better: ” whereupon he went away, and burned it: but he meant, “ Wert thou to spend its price for flour to make bread, or for fire-wood with which to cook, it were better for thee: ” as though he disliked a garment so dyed. (IAth.)
The surface of the ground: (T, S, M, K:) so in the Kur ubi suprà, (T, S,) accord. to 'Alee (S) and I'Ab. (TA.)
The highest part of the earth or ground: so in the same passages of the Kur accord. to Katádeh. (TA.)
Any place from which water pours forth. (M, K.)
A place where the water of a valley collects. (M, K.)

The shining of the dawn: so accord. to some in the Kur ubi suprà: (T:) and 'Alee is related to have said that wafaAra AltRanRuwru means and daybreak rose or rises: (TA:) or it relates to the welling forth of water from the place of the mosque of El-Koofeh: (T:) or AltRnRwr here signifies a well-known spring of water: (Hr, TA:) or a certain mountain near El-Maseesah; (I'Ab, K, TA;) i. e., (TA,) 'Eyn-el-Ward, in El-Jezeereh; (I'Ab, T, TA;) or 'Eyn-Wardeh. (Bd in xi. 42.)
tanRuwriIRN: see tanRaArN.

tunRafN, [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] applied to [deserts such as are termed] tanaAYif, [pl. of tanuwfap,] meaning Of which the extremities are far apart; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) wide, or spacious. (Ibn- 'Abbád.)

tanuwfapN (T, S, M, K, &c.) and tatuwfiyRapN↓, (S, K,) like dawRN and dawRiyRapN, the latter a rel. n. from the former, (S,) A [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap: (T, S, K:) or a land such as is termed qafor [i. e. vacant, or void, or desert, destitute of vegetable produce and of water; or destitute of human beings, but sometimes containing a little herbage or pasturage]: (M:) or a wide, or spacious, land, of which the extremities are far apart: (ElMuärrij, K:) or a desert (falaAp) in which is no water nor any person to cheer one by his company, though it may have, or produce, herbage; (ElMuärrij, T;) so says ISh: (TA:) or a farextending desert, in which is a collection of herbage, but such as cannot be depastured because of its remoteness: (Aboo-Kheyreh, T:) pl. tanaAYifu. (T, M.)
tanuwfiyRapN: see tanuwfapN: and see an ex. voce nacorN.
1. tanama, (M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, tanawRama,]) without teshdeed to the n, (M, TA,) He (a camel) ate the tanRuwm. (M, K.)

tanRuwmN A kind of trees (S, M, K) having a small fruit, (S, M,) like that of the xirowaE [or castor-oil plant], (M,) which, bursting, discloses grains, that are eaten by the people of the desert: (S, M:) as the sun declines, it follows it with the [upper] sides of its leaves: (M:) its fruit, with Hurof, (K,) i. e. HabRu AlrRaXaAdi [q. v.], (TA,) and water, drunk, expels worms; and the application of its leaves, with vinegar, in the manner of a poultice, draws forth warts: (K:) n. un. with p: (S, M, K:) AHn says, it is a kind of dust-coloured trees, of those termed OagolaAv, eaten by ostriches and gazelles, and of those among which gazelles are snared: its grain, when the coverings thereof open, becomes black; and it has a root (Eiroq), sometimes made into a zanod [for producing fire]: the places where it grows are mostly the sides of valleys: IAar says, the tnRwmp is a tree of the kind called janobap, of large size, in which grow grains like hemp-seed, used for ointment, and as a seasoning, or condiment: it dries up at the beginning of winter, and disappears: all this is from AHn: (M:) A'Obeyd says, it is one of the plants of the earth, in which, and in the fruit whereof, is a blackness: it is eaten by the ostrich: the pl.
